My first Bell's but not my last ;).
Well done.

UPDATED: OCT 17, 2013 Aroma of honey lavender caramel and citrus. Like a fine perfume. Taste is a perfect balance of malt and hops. I like hoppier ipas but this is nice. Refreshing.
Gold/amber. Small white head. Lots of lace. Sweet. Citrus, peach, grapefruit. Medium to full body. Velvety, smooth, balanced, great hop finish. Very drinkable and very tasty

Had this beer on tap at Fat Katz. Strong hops were balanced by a nice sweet malt. Easy to drink and a not too heavy mouthfeel with a good finish. 

F Avey---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Very surprised with this one.  Excelent hop aroma lets you know your in for a treat.  Drank form the bottle so cant honestly comment on appearance but very easy to drink with a medium body and just slightly creamy. Ill have to try more from Bells!

Served on-tap at Ciccarellis at 21 and Hayes.

Appearance: It has to be the best beer Ive seen ... behind MAYBE the legendary Guinness. I got it and it had a nice, dark color to it with a beautiful three finger head on it. A thing of beauty. Better yet was the super sticky lacing -- with every sip, you could see the line of how much I drank. Fantastic.

Smell: The smell and taste and a lot of what I got from this was a very deep, pleasant earthy and spicy hoppiness. The smell is much like the taste.

Taste: But the taste is just a BIT better. As nice as it smells, it comes out in every sip. Wonderful balance with the hops... great flavor, with a perfect light bitterness on the finish. I love that I get a taste of Fruit Loops in there, as well as an earthy grit. Delicious.

Mouthfeel: Nice and smooth ... goes down dangerously easy for a 7% ABV.

Overall, a pretty magnificent beer. This has a distinct, strong, pleasant taste to it. As someone thats new to Bells, this and Oberon have made a good first impression on me ... at least on tap. In about a half hour of drinking, I MAY have had my two favorite beers ever. Ill just have to see how they taste in the bottle, though...

This one of the best well balanced ipa around. You can easily drink a six pack and satisfy your hop addiction and yet your taste buds aren't numb. One of Michigans finest. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

This is a near perfect IPA. A perfect balance of hop and malt. Smooth and creamy body and great to drink all day. Top of its style. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

To me- Fruity aroma orange/golden in color. I taste a little salt. Medium body creamy texture soft carbonation with a long finish. Beer goes with everything but I made the mistake of having a Modus Hoperandi with my St Pattys Day corned beef dinner and followed that up with Two Hearts. MH was a better choice at the time.

This beer is locally famous in the midwest so on my recent trip I made a point of having a couple. That being said, this is one of the best IPAs out there. Aroma is a mix of floral and fruity elements, which a rindy grapefuit being predominant. The appearance is what youd expect from mid strength IPA. Tastes very bitter in a flavor filled hop-chewing kind of way, while Id describe the body and chewy and crisp at once. Not a beer you can session with. Had two with St. Patricks brunch before switching to porters, which was a great but foolhardy decision.

Super smooth with pine and citrus notes, a very balanced safe IPA that
I reach for when having one heart just isnt enough.

Pours a clear golden color with a thick foamy three finger head that laces nicely. On the nose its fruity, grassy with a touch of caramel malt. The palate is focused, clean and smooth. Great hoppy fruit presence pineapple, mango and sappy pine lead into a refreshing bitter mid palate that rolls out nicely and lingers with grassy earthy notes. Nice light malt profile. Great Beer thanks Jstax.

Draft: delicious.... Way better on tap, than I remember it tasting in bottles I have had.  Fresh... Bright... Citrusy.  The grapefruit is upfront, and delicious.  Awesome beer, that I ignored for a long time.... Stupid me.

Bottle from New Orleans restaurant in Greensboro.  Dry, lightly bitter and hopped, with a bit of citrus.  Citrus in the aroma, but a bit plain.  Fair but short lived head over a slightly opaque orange beer.  Tastes fairly good.

Appearance: hazy, near marmalade-colored pour with one finger of creamy white head fading to a thick collar; tons of soapy lace curtains sliding down the sides.   Aroma: 	fresh-smelling aromatic hops waft boldly from the head, carrying scents of grapefruit, orange rind, apricots and even strawberries; under all the hops is an aroma of freshly-baked fruitcake.   Taste: bitter hops dominate up front, giving flavors of orange, lemon juice, and resinous pine; a sweet, bready, graham cracker-ish malt tries and largely succeeds to balance.  Finish: the bitterness fades reasonably quickly, but the character of the hop notes actually last  longer, and in the finish they are more flowery than citrusy; as the bitterness fades, the sweet malt, with a hint of molasses, sidles up to round out the end.   Notes: I am an admitted IPA hater, or have been traditionally.  Nevertheless, the style is growing on me like crazy, mainly because of IPAs like this.  Its not bitter for the sake of being bitter; the hops are there to provide a wonderful, aromatic and delicious experience.  The malt bill is not an afterthought, but serves as a perfect foil to what bitterness is there.  I may be an IPA hater, but I love this beer.

Well balanced.  Smooth and crisp.  Perfect everyday beer!  One of my favorite.

Great session beer good smooth taste love it one of my favorites I need to find more like it.

Six pack from whole foods.  Resin hop aroma and hazy copper color with very soapy lacing.  Taste has a unique character - the hops you would expect, balanced out with molasses flavored malt.  Very sticky palate and a lingering grapefruit hop bite on the palate.

One of my absolute favorite IPAs. Beautiful cloudy color with a nice white head. Pine and citrus aroma. The taste is such an awesome balance of bitter hops and rounded malt flavored. I love bell's.
A classic. Pine and grapefruit. Nice malt and hop balance. Finish is so smooth. Good stuff

Bottle to pint glass. Thick, foamy white head. Nice lacing. Excellent pine hop aroma. Slight malty sweetness intermixed with the heavy hop bitterness. One of the better well rounded IPAs on the market. Excellent beer

Bottle pours clear yellow-orange with two finger white foamy head.  Very nice aroma of citrus/floral with a bit of pine.  Taste doesnt seem to follow with a hint of sweetness and citrus dominated by piny hops.  Finish pine hops.

Possibly my favorite IPA of all time, just getting around to reviewing it. Pours a golden orange color with a soft off white head. Smells amazing, lots of orange and citrus, with a bit of piney hop smell. As expected, there is lots of citrus up front, very bright orange flavors. The hops come through on the finish, strong floral, piney flavor and a bit of malt. Medium mouthfeel, average carbonation. Very well balanced, every day drinking IPA.
Pours dark straw with a tight white head. Hoppy nose; like pine/spruce hops. Aroma of sweet spruce hops, hints of citrus. Very decent brew. Taste some kind of sweetness?
Bottle. Pours a darker amber with a medium head. Gigantic floral hop aroma. Hops, citrus and pine with an intense bitter aftertaste.

On tap. Florally hop aroma. Poured a golden amber color, a bit cloudy. Citrusy taste. Drank this literally hundreds of times but this pint is disappointing. I think they need their lines cleaned. Also seems kind of flat.

Such a great beer, love the florally aroma. The floral citrus hop character is what really sells it too me. One of my favorite year round Ipas.

12oz Draft A- Pours clear amber with an offwhite frothy head. Good retention/lacing. S - Citrus hops, apricot in particilar. Also getting some floral notes. T - Beautifully Balanced! Solid malt backbone. Lemon rind. Citrus hops. M - Medium bodied. Nice carbonation. Long hop finish, but not over the top. O - Pinnacle of everyday IPAs! Take this over a west coast style IPA any day.
This was highly satisfying after a long day at work. Goes perfecly with a good blues band!

UPDATED: MAR 5, 2013 Pours a golden amber, thick white head.

Pine and citrus to the nose. Feels like a hop and grapefruit bite on the tongue.  No bready smell or taste like the previous bottle. Grabs my mouth a bit more than the last bottle.   On this tasting I am increasing the aroma from 8 to 9, and increasing taste from 6 to 8.


My first rating was 2/26/13 - 3.80 - I was warned that this beer wasnt going to be as good as I was expecting it to be...

Pours a mildly hazy golden brown. White head that quickly dissipates. Minimal lacing. Good hop floral note to the nose. Very light on the tongue, slight bready taste, citrus, pine. Not the palette kick I was hoping for.

-To IPA is to be.
My favorite IPA, balanced hop and floral aroma and taste. Dry full bodied palate.
Growler fill from great Bells tasting dinner last night at Grovewood Tavern. One of 6 beers we sampled
Amongst my favorite ipas. Bells knows how to make a good beer and this doesnt disappoint.
Found this on draft in Columbus. Incredibly balanced with a strong hop presence. Slightly sweet and citrusy with a bite that sticks around for a minute. One if my favorites.

UPDATED: DEC 28, 2013 Bottle at home. Pours medium amber.  Muted floral aroma (bottled two months ago). Taste is crisp, with beautiful balance of bitter/sweet. Nicely carbonated and dry in the mouth. A classic.
Hoppy aroma and amber pour with large frothy head. Taste is super well balanced and full of different citrus and floral tones. Finishes crisp and dry for an amazing IPA

Amazingly well rounded in all aspects. Glorious hops profile. Nearly a perfect IPA in my books.

Citrus and light mango aroma. Slight hops bitterness with citrus flavoring. Good carbonation and palate feel. Overall very nice beer.

This tastes exactly like an IPA should taste. Perfect and citrusy. Better than Pliny the Younger on draft, but Pliny is better in a bottle. One of my favorite beers. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottled December 26, 2012.
Appearance: What a great looking IPA. The body is a clear amber with some carbonation showing in the body, the head is a thick white mess with great retention.
Aroma: The aroma is light, pine comes to mind first with slight spice and some citrus. I wish it were stronger.
Taste: The flavor is balanced, toasted malts with floral hops that dry out on the finish, hints of pine and citrus, but overall a bit bland. This is balanced nicely, but it needs some character.
Palate: Light to medium bodied, very light carbonation.
Overall: I dont get the huge love for this beer, I guess I simply like my beers a bit bolder. This is balanced well, but the hops and malts are too faint, I prefer something a bit bolder.
Already a classic for me. For many years I have enjoyed this IPA. Nice balance of spicy hops and caramel malt. A bit darker in color than many other IPAs, but perhaps thats what I like.

Bottle. I went through a case of this gradually over the course of a couple weeks, and I really can't grasp what makes Two Hearted so special. It isn't a bad beer by any means, but I think it's the only "top 50" beer that I've tasted that doesn't seem to warrant its position. Two each his own I suppose. (Get it?)
This is my go to, available all of the time beer (and was the main beer attraction at my wedding.)
Starts out with a kick to the tastebuds, then smooths out into a fine drink. Overall a pleasing beer, but not the 100 rating I saw from another site.

On draft, pours golden orange with a thick fluffy white head.  Excellent aroma with notes of peppercorn and citrus.  Very sweet flavor leads into a huge but balanced hop finish.  

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

It pours a clear, bright orange and gives the same color body with a decent foamy one centimeter white head and has some nice spider web lacing along the sides of the glass. No carbonation is seen rising. The smell has the orange up front with some hops tingling in the background. The taste has the previously mentioned flavors balanced really well. The palate is about a light to medium with nothing sharp on the tongue, thoroughly smooth. Though a fairly high ABV, there is a drinkable quality to this beer. Overall, this is one of the best American IPAs on the market!
UPDATED: FEB 6, 2013 Bottle.  Hops hit you hard up front like a punch to your mouth but then back away clean and crisp.  A very enjoyable IPA to drink.
My wife was not a beer drinker until she tasted Two Hearted Ale. The floral and citrus notes played a melody on her palate that said, "All beers are not created equal."

12oz bottle (thanks Nyby!) poured into a tulip.  Pours a clear golden color with medium white head.  Nose is citrus and floral; taste is citrus, pine, hops, bitter.  Crisp, balanced, and refreshing, but not unique.
Surely one of the better IPAs out there in a saturated category. Crisp and clean with no hop burn.  Highly recommended.
Bottle. Clean, crisp, malty and hopped up... this is a great IPA, one of my favorites.

26th November 2011Very hazy orange - amber beer, tidy white head. Smooth palate, slightly soft and with mild fine carbonation. Semi dry. Nice hops, mostly pine with some floral notes and lesser peach and tangerine. Trace of apricot. Creamy malt base. Finishes semi dry with hops getting minty and imparting a little bitterness. Good stuff - so very drinkable.

Pours a slightly cloudy, bright, golden orange color with a finger length white head that dissipates fairly quickly and leaves a thick blanket of lacing. Smells of dank hops. Get grapefruit, tangerine, spicy pine, lots of floral, maybe some lemon. Get a faint hint of breadiness and carmel from the malt, but is definitely overpowered by the hop qualities. Taste starts with an abrasive bitterness along with some grapefruit, tangerine, and floral. Then get a little more malt than the smell suggests. Slight sweetness as well as some bready qualities to somewhat balance the hops. Then the finish returns the abrasive bitterness along with spicy pine, grapefruit, a little orange, floral. Get almost a bubblegum finish when it warms due to the malts starting to show though. The carbonation level is high, which somewhat neutralizes the resinous hop qualities and makes for a much more smooth and refreshing IPA. Medium body with a creamy and clean mouthfeel. This is a classic "hopheads" IPA.
Bottle and Draught.  My love affair with Bells continues.  This is a classic IPA.

1/31/13. Bottle dated 12/17/12. 45 days old. Pours cloudy golden color with a fluffy white head. Aroma is crisp, citrus, lightly floral, bitter. Taste is hoppy and bitter, lemon rind, pine, spicy. More bitter than the aroma may suggest. Not a lot of malt being highlighted here. Nice lacing. Clean, crisp mouth feel. Medium carbonation. Really hop-forward. Tastes stronger than the ABV. I enjoyed this but I cant say that I was blown away. Perhaps the bottle was too old. Definitely a well-made IPA and one worth drinking but I cant say too much else about it.
A very well balanced IPA. One of my favorites. Citrus aroma with floral overtones. Taste is not over the top bitter. appearance is a hazy golden.
Slight aroma that hints at Malt and orange at the start with a centennial finish.  Low head with low carbonation.  Overall not a bad IPA.  Was expecting a bit more of a bit with a higher ABV.
One of the best IPAs you can get. Centennial hops all the way. Very clean and crisp.

Lovely crisp, citrus, slight resin aroma. Pours pale, clear, golden-amber. Fluffy white head, sustained and substantive. Slight effervescence. Initial burst of hops, then cloves, with a tactile, warm-creamy center. Medium body. Long, full finish. Definitely hop-forward. Very satisfying.

Amber in color. Tastes sweet and malty. It could have used some more carbonation and bitterness. It's an easy drinker though.

UPDATED: MAR 2, 2013 Rerate with fresh sample.  Awesome grapefruit/orange aroma, small head, awesome orange color to the beer.  Mostly flavors of orange, super well balanced with a decent malt presence.  Really a fantastic representation of what a good IPA is.

Bottle from trade with umich03jm. Been wanting to try this one for quite a while. Pours a typical medium golden color, with a moderate disappearing head, and great hop aroma that is floral and citrus. This a balanced IPA, which I tend to gravitate towards. The hop presence is only moderately bitter, and has some complexity to it that reminds me of citrus. Slightly resinous. Malt presence comes through without being at all sweet. bitter shit. love my bitter lips
Easy to like. Well crafted IPA with nice hop aroma but not overpowered. Find myself going back to it often.
Awesome easy to drink beer. Citrus and malts even out the hops to make a really refreshing brew.

A very solid beer.  Easy to drink but full of flavor.  Something I would order often.

12oz bottle poured into a pint glass. Pours a golden amber color with initially a huge white head and leaves a lot of sticky lacing. Aroma of citrus, hops, malts, and pine. Taste is fresh hops, malts and citrus. Extremely well blended together. Palate is light with a slick texture and low carbonation. Overall this is probably the easiest drinking IPA on the market. I couldnt tell you a single IPA fan that doesnt rank this among their favorites. Top notch and deserving of its ranking.

Draft at MOTR Pub at Scrawl concert on September 15, 2012.  Medium amber color--or at least it appeared that way in the annoying green-tinted Rolling Rock glass it was served in, nice bittersweet aroma with pine and lots of citrus, small white head that slowly left with little lacing, solid bittersweet flavor that kind of creeps up on you, hops and malt well integrated.

One of the best IPAs I have had, but what else would you expect from Bells?
Strong hops taste, not so strong hops aroma (as compared to some others), but still good aroma.  The top rating on this is evidence.
One of the best up ipas Ive ever had.  Color and head are great.  Well balanced beer. Highest ipa trying Ive given.

This is outstanding. Medium gold hazy color on tap. This IPA has a strong citrus aroma. Complexity on the palate is achieved from ample use of hops and malt. The taste starts with a spicy lavender flavor and moves on to citrus and finishes a refreshing bitter. Rich rich rich. One of my favorites

Hazy gold, white head. Floral, perfumy hop aroma, grainy malt with some caramel sweetness, citrusy hop flavor, finishes with some lingering. bitterness. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
A definite score this close to the source. Lots of varied spice here. Pours clear orange with some lacing. Aroma of citrus, ginger and malt. Medium to high carbonation. Bitter leave. Tap at Bells.
I hate that Bells is not in Maryland. Any time I travel to VA, I stock up. Its just plain good. That is all.

UPDATED: APR 20, 2015 Bottle. Golden, hzy, average and mostly lasting head. Moderate, malty and lightly sweetish - sweetish aroma, light caramel and some floral - tropical fruitiness, piney - some grapefruit hoppyness. Body is medium to full, malty and lightly sweetish flavor, light caramel and light floral - tropical fruitiness, piney - grapefruit hoppyness. Finish is average to long, malty and dryish - lightly sweetish with faint caramel and light tropical fruitiness, lots of piney - some grapefruit hoppyness, faint alcohol. Really nice IPA with piney hoppyness. Not too sweet/too much caramel.

12oz bottle into a pint glass.

Pours an almost clear deep orange with just a little bit of sediment winding up in the glass. One finger head slowly fades into a nice fluffy cap over the beer.

Big hoppy aroma that leans more towards pine rather than fruit. There is some orange and pineapple but this one steers away from the super tropical. Real nice bready malt notes underneath giving the aroma a great balance.

Lots of pine and earth upon tasting with hardly a hint of fruit. Quite assertive maltyness too lending an really nice balance. Strong bitterness throughout but very appropriate for the style. For not being strong on fruity hops, the beer has a real "juicy" character that is refreshing. Mouthfeel is full but a little too sticky for my liking.

Overall, a very nicely balanced IPA and one of the better ones that is widely available. Not Earth-shattering by any means but one to definitely enjoy regularly.

Amber with gold highlights.  Small white head with decent lacing and moderate, tight carbonation.  Grassy and somewhat floral aroma with caramel sweetness.  Sweetness hits first but is quickly overtaken by grassy hop bitterness.  Some yeast and bread comes in at end with bitterness lightly lingering.  Moderate and lively mouthfeel with plenty of carbonation and with some stickiness.  Good American IPA even though they are not my favorite.  I like the slight sweetness and that the bitterness isn't too astringent or overpowering.   

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle. I've enjoyed this for years and this bottle is just as good as the first. Great hop and citrus nose; near perfect color for the ipa. Medium off white head and initial smooth mouthfeel. Great body and the hop and citrus bond well together. This is a great go-to beer. Almost sad it's 7%+ since it would be nice to not have to worry about them creeping up on you. 

---Rated via my mouth

Pale gold in color poured from a bottle. Floral and citrus hop aromas are present. No malt taste - very light bodied. Accentuates the earthy and grapefruit like hop flavor. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Somewhat cloudy brass body, two-finger bone-white head. good retention.
Beauuuutiful. Perfumey floral and citrus hop notes. You can smell it at arms length. Just gorgeous.
Perfect level of sweetness with just enough bitterness to balance it. 
Amazingly smooth. The carbonation is present but unobtrusive.
This has got to be one of the best American IPAs out there today. I adore this beer.

UPDATED: DEC 20, 2014 Notes from 1/5/12 at pipers pub, have had this beer several times and its great.Strong citrus aroma, lacing significant, strong grape fruit flavor balanced bitterness, lingering citrus flavor and bitterness, very tasty, great beer, cheap for a case compared to other craft beers at this level one of the best pale ales I've had.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Strong citrus nose, first hops flavor that hits the pallate is very citrusy folloqed by a slow bittering that is amazing. One of Bells best.

One of my favorite ales of all time. A great mix between hop forwardness and malt backbone. Hits the tongue with an initial bitter bite, with some sweetness to follow. It has a pleasant lasting dry and bitter aftertaste. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

This is a well-made right in the Middle IPA between being over hoppy and to malty. A clean nice aftertaste left on the palate very smooth and easy to drink. I would drink it again poured from a bottle.  Big Mikes Brevard NC

On tap.  Pours a clear light golden amber with a small head that has decent retention and leaves some light lacing on the glass.  The aroma is sugar cookie with a lot of grapefruit and some orange as well.  There are also some light floral notes.  The initial taste is sweet with some sugar cookie and a bunch of grapefruit and a bit of orange as well as a bit of caramel.  The finish has a mild bitterness as well as quite a bit of sweetness.  Medium-light bodied.  Relatively low carbonation.  A bit more sweetness than I would like, but a pretty solid IPA, especially for one that is regularly available.
Delicious. Smooth and super tastey. One of the best ales Ive had. Jfjfjfjfjjfjndjjdjfjgifjjeudhhf

Just malty and hoppy enough to be the best all around beer Ive ever had. It doesnt shout in any particular direction, preferring instead to be perfect in each. I consider this to be the archetype of beer; all other beer is beer only as it relates to Bells Two Hearted Ale.

Golden orange pour.  Nose is floral and herbal hops.  Not huge but just right.  Taste is somewhat bitter.  Very smooth.  No lingering hops.  Very good ipa.  Probably as good as it gets for a standard floral ipa.
On tap.  Hazy copper pour.  Taste hoppy with some pine.  Bitter finish.  Solid IPA.
Bottle pour.  A very pleasant floral aroma upon pouring.  Tastes like awesome.

Crack the cap and smell the hops. Very flowery hops aroma.  Dark golden brown color with a nice head. Awakens your tongue with the strong hops flavor. Absolutely one of my favorites. Although I dont recommend an entire 6 pack in a sitting. You will pay for it.

Bottle. Pours bright, hazy amber with average, creamy off-white head; short retention and spare lacing. Aroma is bread and cookie malts, oranges, pears, floral and citrus hops, and sugar. Flavor is citrus and pine hops forward (medium bitterness) with good supporting sweet malts and light fruit esters; dry finish. Medium body and low carbonation.

UPDATED: APR 1, 2017 Tasty high gravity beer at pit... Pawleys island tavern.. Good times...! Tasty beer..... Second rating: very nice citrus/strawberry smell...sweet malt on front...hoppy bitter on back but not overwhelming...good mix, bitterness sticks around a while though...second time at publick house

From bottle to glass. Massive citrus aroma of orange. Pours slightly hazy deep orange with a full off-white head. Great orange citrus flavor bursting throughout. Aggressive bitter finish balanced nicely by supportive malt background. Medium-full mouthfeel with covering qualities from the nice hop resin.

Got this bad boy on tap at Elles on Main. Poured a nice transparent amber.  Got her in a collector edition Bud Light NFL pint glass. Spilt most of it on the dance floor while trying to grind on girls I knew in high school. Usually a Miller guy, but when I tried it I said "Hot damn thats got hops or something!" Real clean finish, nice drink ability. Cant wait to try this gem again.

Bottle from an American friend. Instant attack of hops on the nose from the moment of opening. Beautiful straw color with persistent light white head. Intensely bitter without tons of caramel sweetness on the back like some IPAs get. This is a quintessential American craft IPA. Cant go wrong with this if looking for the style. Does not taste of its abv, another indication of balance.

Aromas of pine, dank pineapple and light citrus.

Bottle from my secret Santa, located in Ohio. Pours clear golden with a big creamy snow white head. Aroma is strong citrussy and resiny hops, pineapple as well. Well balanced taste, despite the massive hop attack from the start, resiny, flowery and strong citrus all the way to the light bitter and dry finish. Solid malty body underneath, well crafted, a solid IPA.
Bottle pour.  Great IPA thatll stand up to the likes of those greats like Surly Furious.
I remember this being very good.  Something about this beer tasted a little funny to me, but I dont really recall what it was as I got pretty lit up later in the night.
This is by far my favorite ipa that i have found so far.  It has a strong scent dark appearance.  but the taste is ridiculous.  finishes clean makes you want to always have just one more.

Id be lying if I said the Hemingway tie in didnt put me in this beers corner before even tasting it - but it helps that its an amazing beer too. On tap @ Minnosa, MSP. Pours cloudy golden with an orange tint and medium thin slightly oily head. Aroma is big hops: citrus dominates, with pine and earthy notes following. Taste is punchy hop-forward and crisp. The hops really jump out much more on tap as I tried a bottle just yesterday. Hops are super fresh: citrusy, floral, and earthy. Malts are smart enough to stay out of the way and let the hops shine here. Exactly what an IPA should be.

Draft. Pours golden with small white head. Floral piney aromas. Lost of hop flavor but not overwhelming. There is a good malt balance in this beer. Finishes with lingering floral hop flavors. Very good beer. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

22 is my lucky number and this is my lucky 22nd rating! I saved this beer for it because it is my favorite beer of all time and the beer that broke me into craft beer. I remember the first time I had a lady, the first time I met Mary Jane, and the first time I had a Two Hearted. I was headed on a trip to the west side of the mitten with a lady to do some camping many years ago and on a whim (maybe it was the hemingway-esque line) I picked up a sixer of this brew. I stuffed it into the cooler and proceeded to our camp spot, it was of course raining cats + dogs and nearly impossible to make camp. I reached into the cooler and pulled out an icy cold bottle in the hot humid car and took a sip. My life was changed forever, seriously. I cant lie though a couple of summers ago I cheated on Two Hearted with Founders Centennial and I thought it might best it, but absence made the heart grow fonder and I found my way back home to My beloved 2<3ed. I feel blessed to be a Michigander and claim this as my everyday IPA, doubt Ill ever put out another 5 ever but I had to for this one. Tonight I had it on tap @ the Union Woodshop into  a mason jar, beautiful orange glow and thumbs worth of off-white head. Smells of flowers in spring and crisp fresh lake air. Taste is impeccable for a single hop (centennial) IPA, balanced, crisp without biting, citrusy, very light pine. Simply tremendous mouthfeel and finish. Also the phenomena of Two Hearted burps is unlike any other IPA I have ever drank. Seek this beer out if you have not had it and enjoy.

Aggressive pine and citrus and floral hops are balanced with the malt sweetness to make a supremely drinkable hop bomb IPA.  One of my favorites.  Don't bother cells ring.  These guys are best fresh when the hops are in your face.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Excellent hop aroma and nice head from the pour from the bottle. The color was a little cloudy, but the flavor matched the hoppy nose. Its a well balanced IPA with hops . Great beer from bells

Bottle. Pours orange with medium head and quite a bit if lacing. Aroma of citrus. Very well balanced. Hops galore on the front end but crisp on the back end. Masterpiece. 

----Hophaze out

Awesome! Pours dark golden with little head or lacing. Nose is fruity. Aromas are fruit, floral, some citrus hops. Tastes are light sweet and great medium bitter finish. Mouth is medium body with lively carbonation.
Nice aroma very balanced hops. It pours golden with a fair amount of lacing. Very sessionable beer.

UPDATED: DEC 23, 2015 had to re-rate this now that i have had so many great beers.  this one is way too malty.  slight hoppy bitter finish.  pours copper with a sticky white head.  had a draft at south branch.

Interestingly, the only hops used in this are Centennial. Light orange color with a massive, rocky head. Aroma is overloaded with the Centennial hops. Surprisingly light body. Flavors of orange, grapefruit, and caramel. Super hoppy brew. Almost makes you pucker. Hops stick around for a long time in both flavor and bitterness.

Nothing to hide here. Just a ton of Centennial hops and 7% ABV. Hop heads will love it!

Sweet citrusy aroma with about a finger of slightly off white head that dissipates quickly. Hazy dark copper pour. Sweet with a long lasting hop taste at the end. Great beer! 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Probably my favorite beer. citrus flavor with a bitter after-note, but not over the top like some IPAs.  To sum it up short, bittersweet in the best way.
It has that perfect amount of haze for me.  This beer lived up to the hype Ive read about.  It is the bar at which I compare all beers going forward.

Bottle from trade. Enjoyed at cellar temperature. Gold with orange hues with some particles suspended in the liquid. Great flavor of vibrant citrus hops that is balanced perfectly by some sweet malts. Flavors of peach, grapefruit and light grain. Low carbonation, yet enough to give a light tingle on the tongue. Medium body, mouthfeel being dry and crisp. This is a step above most other standard IPAs. Not much else to say other than this is excellent.

Bells. Delicious brew. One of the best palates on an ale I have ever had. Drink it

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

12 ounce bottle. Hazy amber orange color, lots of bubbles. thick bubbly white head. Fragrant grapefruit hop aroma. Tangy toasted malt flavor mixed with a citrusy hop character. Well balanced with a bitter citrus hop finish. Delicious.

Pours a translucent amber with a medium, white head.  Excellent lacing.  Balanced aroma -- strong with hops, but not overbearing.  Creamy, slightly effervescent mouthfeel.  Taste is an exceptional balance of malts and hops -- slightly bitter, but not brutally so.  Slight citrus notes.  Pleasant finish.  Great brew.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for the Daystrom M-5

12oz fish-labeled bottle poured into snifter glass.  Light orange color with thin off-white head.  Aroma of citrus (orange, pineapple, peach) and floral hops.  Taste is almost fruity, nicely balanced with sweet malt.  Medium body, some lingering finish. Very fruity IPA.  I like!
Absolutely wonderful IPA.  Possibly my all-time favorite.  Very balanced between the hops and malt.
Very well balanced with a smooth finish and delicious hop kick. I could drink this all day.

(bottle) pours a clear golden colour with a frothy white head. aroma of bubble gum, grapefruit and banana, with a hint of caramel, some white grapes, honey melon and light raisins. flavour is mostly the same, though the fruitiness is slightly subdued, with notes of bubble gum, herbal hops, light caramel and a subdued maltiness, slightly minerally in the medium-bitter finish. medium-bodied with average carbonation. wasnt expecting it to be so balanced and mellow.
This is one hell of an IPA. Perfect hop balance and malt presence, with a nice character. Lots of floral notes and a strong aroma with an incredibly fresh finish. A lively IPA.

Drank from bottle poured into short pilsner. Wonderful hops aroma with a bit of floral and fruitiness. Beautiful peach and gold color slightly cloudy with minimal head. Taste has bitterness of hops with a juicy, fruity, floral finish. Palate is dry and bitter from the hops with a lingering juicy sweetness, very nice!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Drank out of 12 oz bottle in short pilsner glass. Aroma- my favorite smell! Wonderful hop notes with a bit of lemon. Appearance- golden yellow/orange. Light head and carbonation. Taste- very smooooth and good amount of hops. could drink quite a few of these. Palate- very clean mouthfeel with light hop residue. Overall- one of my favorite IPAs but would have to give Ballast Point sculpin the nod by just a little due to sculpin leaving a more lasting impression, but i could drink this one all night

Bottle from the brewery. Pours a very hazy orange gold with a good amount of white head which dissipates slowly. Smell is very hoppy, mostly citrus with a bit of tree, a good mix. Palate is on the lighter side of medium bodied, but has a mouth filling carbonation that really helps spread the flavour. Taste is quite bitter at first, then less bitter, then has a definite citrus peel aftertaste, very very nice.
Smooth and textured,  robust and flavorful. A great overall India pale ale. I would highly recommend this brew.
Aroma is the driver in the taste of this beer. Big floral scents, crisp taste, clean finish. Not over powering happiness but assertive.
Sampled in a 12 oz bottle. Pours light orange with a thin white head. Has a mild hoppy aroma and big time hop flavor.
Bottle. Great beer. Aroma is orange and citrus. Complex hop flavor. It had a perfectly acceptable malt body to keep the balance intact.
Hand pull at bettys. Pours cloudy orange big fluffy head. I can smell the citrus and pineapple from six feet away. Taste is very smoth hop and lots of tropical fruit best way I have had this beer
UPDATED: MAY 21, 2014 Great every time beer from bells. Had it on tap in Ann Arbor. Gotta come back for more. Great ale.

Solid ipa with nice hop aroma, nice pine    And citrus notes, I will buy again

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Great beer! Perfectly crisp, complex hop flavor. It had a perfectly acceptable malt body to keep the balance intact. One of the best pours ive ever seen!
Pours a golden-amber color with a crisp hoppy scent. Flavor has a wonderful hoppy bite. Not much else but thats all you need sometimes.
Fantastic beer. This was the beer that got me hooked on IPA. Crisp bouquet, hoppy yet mild flavor.

12 oz bottle served in pint glass.

Pours a hazy yellow gold with a moderate amount of ecru head. The head has medium retention and leaves plenty of lacing.   Aroma features delightful lemon/orange hops ("Hopped exclusively with the Centennial hop varietal from the Pacific Northwest") with toasted caramel malt in the background. Fresh and a bit floral. Irresistible. Tastes like a fresh hop brew. Higher ABV not evident. Excellent sweet/bitter balance with a delightful dynamic interplay. 

Medium/light body with good, if slightly aggressive carbonation. Some nice dryness in the finish.

Great flavor and aroma; Id love to try a souped-up imperial version.

Sweet malt aroma. Slight piney aroma. Some spiciness as well. Dark gold color with high clarity. Moderate malt flavor with a piney hop flavor. A hint of peach-like flavor. Medium body. Medium carbonation. Some alcohol warming. Very enjoyable beer.
On draft at church key in Washington DC.  Pours an al;most clear pale amber with a white head.  Mandarin orange in the nose.  Full mouth feel with a bitter finish.

UPDATED: JAN 5, 2015 Update:  From a can, just under 4 months old.  Not sure why this beer is so variable for me, but this can was certainly better than my last experience.  Its been a rocky road, but I think I am starting to understand this beer.  Its a solid example of its corner of the IPA world.  
Im about to give up on this beer.  I intentionally bought a relatively fresh bottle just to make sure Im not crazy.  Pours a pale gold with head fading to a film leaving decent lacing.  Aroma is slight floral and citrus, but mainly dominated by grain and wheat.  More tart when swirled, but there are no hops at all here.  This bottle was less than two months old.  Not as fresh as can be, but Bells themselves say the shelf life for Two Hearted is 6 months(!).  I hate to rate lower for something I know isnt a good representation...but then again Ive had Surly Furious thats 6 months old and still retains 90% of the hop feel.  This must be a delicate beer.  Taste is sweet and grainy up front, then finally some hop bitterness in the middle, ending decently, but still holding on to some of the sweet grains.  Almost, dare I say, an adjunct feel to this one.   I want to like this one, but Im having a hard time.  
This beer is different every time.  This bottle was 2.5 months old, so not sure how that affects it.  Pours a pale gold with pillowy white head and lots of bubbles.  This bottles aroma was balanced between fruity hops and sweet malts.  Subdued but good.   Taste is very balanced, restrained, almost mild.  Very good balance of hops and malts.  This is a subtle IPA with no evidence of alcohol.  Palate is creamy and smooth.  This is an IPA that wont offend anyone.  Still, why does it taste different every time I review it.  This ones bitterness was nowhere near "strong" like last time.  8+5+8+5+14=4.0

Pours a golden orange with small white lasting head.  Aroma is sweet, full, and balanced - really good.  Taste is similar, but the resiny bitterness is just slightly too strong at the end.  Smooth, crisp, and unique.  Moderately bitter at the end - maybe a little too much? 9+4+8+4+14 = 3.9

Pours a cloudy golden orange with head dissipating into a ring around the edge.  Aroma is citrus - grapefruit.  Lively carbonation, a bitter shot of hops, followed by a slight bready malt balance, then right back to a bitter aftertaste on the sides of your tongue.  Slightly metallic aftertaste.  This is not a bad beer, but for me it was more of an "OK" IPA rather than "top-notch".  7+4+7+4+10=3.2
Bottle->SA glass.  Pale gold, hop and citrus aroma.  Taste is solid straightforward hoppy IPA.  The epitome of an excellent IPA.
Really good overall! They make great IPAs; solid, balanced yet intriguing. Plenty of technical reviews. If you like IPAs, drink this one!

Draught at Akkurat. Almost clear amber liquid with medium to high off-white head. Aroma of citrus, grapefruit, tropical fruit, light biscuit and some very fresh hops. Taste is dry and medium bitter. Very balanced. Notes of grapefruit, citrus and tropical fruit. Medium bodied with medium carbonation Awesome stuff.
12 ounce bottle.  Pours a pale gold with a decent white head.  Aroma of florals, pine, citrus, and malt.  Taste is the same.  Very well balance.  Very well done!

This was very enjoyable. Nice citrus in the nose. Aroma reminded me more of an APA than what I think of in an IPA. More mellow and malty in the body than an APA. Nice bitterness. Citrus again in the mouth, but also some doughy/bread flavor as well
Great, reliable beer. Not a kick in the face, but a soft, smooth IPA that is very consistently good.
One of my all time favorite. Pours a pale light amber color with a full hop aroma and a sweetness to it. Small lemon aftertaste with a medium body.

Not that impressed sadly...Ive bought a six pack of this stuff and it was..eh.  Then I bought the mini or pony keg, twice and it was..eh.  Now prior to these last three purchases of THA Ive had great pleasure drinking this beer, in fact it was my first beer where I was told what kind of beer I was drinking and not just one of the big three breweries.  The beer I currently drink is ok.  I wouldnt turn it down if the other alternatives were the MCB trio, but I cant but feel duped.."I bought this again?"

Had on tap at the Yardhouse in Glenview. Served in a pint glass.

A: Pours a slight hazy amber with golden yellow edges. A very bubbly one finger white head forms on the pour and leaves some sticky, splotchy lace down the glass.

S: Subtle citrus notes with some candied fruit sweetness mixed in for good measure.

T: This just explodes in my mouth and is definitely one of the sweeter IPAs Ive ever had. Sweet pears and apples are present with a nice candied fruit and honey finish. Pale malts are present throughout, but take a back seat.

M: Medium to light bodied with a sweet and semi-bitter finish. Its come in and out like a nice little combo kicking my toungue long after the beer has left.

O: Even though this was sweeter than I expected it was never overpowering. Highly drinkable and another great go to beer when fresh.

Serving type: on-tap

Reviewed on: 12-16-2011

A simple beer made with two row, crystal malt and Centennial hops.  Notes of caramel, citrus, light pine and very light floral..  There is something in the aroma that reminds me of a mild Belgian yeast.  Its one of the least bitter IPAs Ive tried.  It drinks like a 35ibu pale ale.  Perhaps this is why its so highly rated?  Im not a fan of super bitter IPAs, so this one goes down nicely.

UPDATED: MAY 9, 2013 Draught @ Akkurat, Stockholm
Originally rated on 05.10.2012 - 
Pours dark orange with a large foamy white head. Aroma of fruity hops, hints of caramel malts, lemon and citrus. Taste is quite malty with hints of fruity but a bit aged hops, citrus, caramel and grass.
Finish is bitter and slightly hoppy with hints of caramely malts. Unfortunately this probably wasnt very fresh, feels a bit unbalanced. Would like to try this from a fresh bottle.

Re-rated on 9.5.2013 @ Super IPA Tasting, 355ml bottle from cp45, thanks! Bottled 03/05/13. 
Not that different from the draught version. Still quite malty, grainy and not that fruity or fresh. A bit disappointing. 10 years ago this would have been something special, but now its just another generic IPA.
If I find a better IPA I would be surprised! Very easy to drink. Great mix of hops and citrus flavor. Recommended for any fan of IPAs.

UPDATED: JUN 10, 2015 My go to beer. Period. The perfect IPA, with a hint of sweetness and great hop-citrus balance. Not much meets the standard set by this one.

An old go-to, but have to downgrade these days, as it is no longer standing up to the amazing stuff out there. Still, easy drinking and approachable IPA. Maybe the most approachable high level IPA on the market. Good stuff.

Standard head with minimum lacing. Tropical fruit hop nose. Very balanced malt and hops, immensely drinkable. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

On tap @ Churchkey.  Poured a cloudy light amber with reddish hues a medium tan head and excellent lacing.  Aroma begins with floral and pine hoppiness followed by citrus zest and caramel malt.  Taste is extraordinarily smooth with just the right amount of bitterness balanced by citrus, grapefruit, and malt.  Nice sticky mouthfeel after a crisp finish.  One of the most drinkable complex IPAs I have ever had.

Pours a carbonated, slightly cloudy orange/red with a white head.  Aroma is a good balance of grapefruit, lemon, spice, pine, and some floral notes.  Taste is big in pine with hops and grapefruit underneath.  It is dry and bitter, leaving a strong pine aftertaste.  Plenty of lacing is left behind.  This one is light in body, crisp and refreshing.  Lots of positives here.  This is a first class offering in this style.

The head is robust, the body orange-brown. It smells very hoppy, citrus, fruity aromatic. A lot of different kinds of hops in a full bodied smell, nice! Tastes different hoppy, orange and lemon peels, very aromatic a bit bitter, citrus-bitter, different hops. Fantastic  IPA!

Great beer! Nice citrus notes and bitterness that are not overpowering and well balanced. A new favorite!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
As if you couldnt tell from the 100 rating. Move to Kalamazoo so you can get this close to the brewery. Im serious. Call U-Haul. Its worth it.

Aroma is hopped with a nice sweet and sour edge. Color is a bit pale, but has a nice head. Taste is full if hop, with the pine nicely balancing, and not too sweet. Palate is smooth, not the overly sweet approach most use to counter the strong hop character. Very filling, hard to drink too much.

this is a great beer.  bitter and sweet at the same time.  floral, but not in a sickening way.  not too heavy to drink a few.  strong enough to let you know youve had a few.  always an excellent choice.
Nose of citrus fruits and pine. Incredible taste of bitterness and smoothness melded perfectly. Finish is a nice bitter with a creamy palate. Great beer.
Fantastic everyday IPA, strong hops bite, grapefruit bitterness indicative of a nicely balanced beer of this style

UPDATED: JUL 24, 2014 Bright golden in color with a big head, the aroma is big, bright hops and citrus, and the flavor is mild and buttery as it introduces itself, and then has a big, piney, bitter bite at the end.  This isnt as big as the IPAs Ive really enjoyed lately, but its pretty tasty.
Pours clear light amber with thin white head. Taste is slightly bitter with a mellow malty undertone. Clears the palate instantly but leaves it crisp and refreshed. Great beer but not blown away.

I remember having this several years ago and thinking it may be the best beer I have ever had.  I dont know if the beer has changed, or it is due to the numerous excellent beers I have had since then, but for some reason it is not what I expected.  It definitely cannot hang with the DIPAs but then again that isnt really a fair comparison.  

Pours a slightly hazy orange/gold color with minimal head.  Aroma smells fresh with strong floral notes.  Taste is some malt sweetness with a nice bitter finish that lingers for a while.  The body is medium and overall the beer is very crisp and fresh.  

Dont get me wrong, I think this is a very nice beer but it is not how I remembered it.  Next up is the Lagunitas Wilco Tango Foxtrot (WTF) Ale.  I need something a little stronger.

120z. bottle from Publix- Dallas, GA --->shaker.  Pours light amber with small white head that disappeared quickly with good lacing.  Aroma is sweet florals, minor pine, and malt.  Taste mimics aroma.  Palate is kind of thin and watery.  I can only assume that this bottle wasnt very fresh, because this is definately not a 100.  Solid beer, and not horrible, but just simply good.
UPDATED: NOV 22, 2012 Cant believe I am just getting around to rating this one.  My favorite IPA.  The IPA by which all others should be judged.  Go out and get some today.

A: A bright golden color. See through, rich amber. The head was surprisingly thick and solid. Biteable even. Leaves a very nice lacing. 

S: Slightly fruity smell, but just slightly. Nice. 

T: When cold, it has that crisp bitterness that masks any subtlety. 
It has an odd, fishy aftertaste that reminds me of lake water... but thats probably because of the bottle label. Unfortunately as it warms up it gets noticeably sour. Like warm, old orange juice. (personal experience. Dont ask.) 

M: Crisp, significant carbonation. A slight greasy feel that goes away quickly. 

Not bad. No danger of it becoming my favorite beer, but certainly wouldnt turn one down if offered. I like it better cold, unlike most darker beers, and ales in general for that matter. Cold and out of the bottle instead of in a glass, its actually very good. 
And for that I bump drinkability from 3.5 to 4.

UPDATED: MAY 20, 2016 Aroma is grapefruit, piny, citrus. Appearance is amber, burnt orange. Taste is grapefruit, sweet, bitter from the hops, piny. Mouthfeel is ok, typical for an IPA. Overall, this is my go-to IPA, and because I live in Michigan, it is regularly on tap even in places not prone to selling good craft beer. I love this beer.

UPDATED: APR 11, 2015 Pours a deep reach orange amber with head that is thick.  Aromas of hops and pine.  Complex flavors of hops, citrus, a hint of berries, and a strong hop finish...however with an overall smoothness that is pleasant.  Pleasantly surprised by this one.

Clear medium gold, with a soft nice lacy lasting thin head. Wonderful clean citrus smell, hops, grapefruit, malt and light orange. Thin light body. Refined, sweet malt taste put up against a nice citrus bitter orange finish. So smooth to drink. And very easy to drink. Delicious.
UPDATED: OCT 24, 2012 A good ipa but none one of my favorites. Decent hop flavors with mainly pine shining through. Very drinkable but nothing unique about this beer.

overall one of the best commercial ipas you can find. bells has another great beer

This is the standard for IPAs that all others should be judged against. Simply the best beer anywhere

I have had this beer many times over the years, and am quite overdue to write a review.

The appearance is clear and light orange hued. The head stands in at around an inch thick, displays lasting retention and leaving ample lacing on the pint glass. The aroma is not particularly grand, but is pleasant nonetheless. Scents include malt, floral notes, light pine. The flavor is tasty, and though the beer is primarily hop forward, it definitely has a strong malt backbone. This is a good example of what I would consider a "balanced" IPA. Though I prefer beers of this ilk to be lighter on the palate and more hop forward with a pronounced citrus component, there is no denying that Bells Two Hearted Ale is a tasty brew. Additionally, I think this beer, like many IPAs, is a notch better on draft versus the bottle.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 05-06-2011
"Floral" is probably the strongest characteristic accompanying the hops.  Pours a reddish brown and finishes bitter. Great with food, like a thick burger and fries.
This beer was pretty good it was not as strong as I would like it to be but it was very smooth

Clear yellow pour with a frothy, fully lasting, off-white head. Aroma is moderate malt, heavy hops and strong grapefruit.  Flavor is moderate sweet and bitter with average duration. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft.
Cut a grapefruit in half. Squeeze the juice out with your bare hands. Now smell your fingers. Thats what centennial hops remind me of and thats Two Hearted. A perfectly executed beer, in every way.

UPDATED: NOV 10, 2012 Tap at eccentric. [FRESH!]

Not the most bitter IPA, or intense in any way, but just so solid.  Great sweet grapefruit and tropical fruit, pine, and herbal notes.  Pours a vibrant orange/yellow with a bright white head.  Tastes bitter with a bready malt character.  Feels amazing.  Just a fantastic IPA

First let me start off by saying that I LOVE bells, almost as much as I love bitter and floral IPAs, but Ive had terrible experiences with this brew. Having first tried it a few years back, I was convinced that I had encountered a several tainted batch, and many who had lamented this beer had came to the same conclusion because a beer so lauded shouldnt taste so poor.

In the simplest description, this beer tastes like pond water to me, although it does not smell that way. I do believe theres a small group of people out there who have a distribution of taste buds that pull out this "pond water" flavor over all the hops and alcohol. 

Im writing this review less to remonstrate this beer and more to make other reviewers aware that if you taste "pond water," then you best move on, and sort this beer as a strange anomaly of an IPA. Its not a bad batch, its just a bad match, one I do not hold against Bells in the slightest.

Cheers.

Bottle Vines, Dr. Phillips. Big pine and citrus resin nose, pours a fine pale amber colour, soft on the tongue, some sweetness with a faintly woody and sherbert finish. Lovely effervescence in the mouth. Good IPA.

UPDATED: MAY 6, 2015 12oz bottle thanks to pellegjr - cheers Joey! Pours hazy orange/golden with thin bright white head - decent lacing. Sweet malt notes balance the hops well, but the bitter hop attack is the main player. Such a crisp & refreshing IPA - loved every sip and cant wait til the next one whenever that might be!
Excellent stuff. The attack on this has an almost acidic bite to it, followed by delicious hop flavor without much bitterness. A very quenching and likable brew, with a very distinct personality.

UPDATED: AUG 17, 2012 Pours slightly unclear orange yellow with frothy white head. Smell is sweet cereal grain with varied fruit and subtle earthy pine and lemon grass hop notes. The hop aromas fade with time, but the beer remains one of the best ipa?s available.  Well balanced bitterness with slight caramel malt profile. One of the best ipa?s available.

Pours a clear golden orange with a frothy white head. Aroma is bursting with hoppy citrus. Mouthfeel is right on very smooth carbonation. UPDATED: FEB 16, 2013 Bottle pour. One of the smoothest IPAs I have ever had. Glorious hop notes, with a fresh finish. I have had a lot of IPAs and this one is not the hoppiest, nor the maltiest. It doesnt have the highest ABV I have ever had or anything like that. But I give it a 4.9 because there is absolutely nothing I would change about this beer. As an experienced homebrewer I often find myself thinking, oh I would add this hop to a beer, oh I would modify this or that. I cannot find anything at all that I would change about two hearted ale. It is far and away the most balanced, best all around beer I may have ever had. Cheers Bells Brewery, thanks for perfecting the American IPA.

Update vs Stone IPA:
Oh man. Here we go. Its rumble time. Im pouring six IPAs tonight, into two identical tulip glasses so I can compare, with this one going head to head with Stone IPA. The two american IPAs, both with 100/100 on ratebeer. Damn, this ought to be fun. Aroma of stone is nice and floral, but Two hearted wins the category. Dont get me wrong, the citrus and glorious honey and hop aroma of stone is great but it has to go up against the two hearted, and two hearteds balanced hop aroma wins. In taste Stone IPA is more hoppy, citrus and floral, but Two hearted is more balanced. Two hearted though just is so unbelievably smooth with all the citrus hops coming through still that I have to give it the category. Two hearteds finish is better as well. Im calling it for Two hearted here. Both are epic, but in a battle of heavyweights the two hearted wins. On to the next!

Into the finished stone glass I poured Bear Republic Racer 5. They look incredibly similar in identical glasses. Two hearted won against stone IPA, can it take down a equally matched racer 5? I think racer 5 wins the aroma category. Both are gloriously hoppy, but the racer has a more hop forward aroma with the obviously floral hops coming out nicely. It smells like the lineup of glorious american hops it has in it, chinooks, cascades, columbus and centennials. Two hearted, hands down wins the taste category though. if only barely. Two hearted is balanced where racer 5 is bold. Both are citrusy with racer 5 bringing out more citrus where two hearted is more floral. Finish though, two hearted wins every time. I honestly dont think it can be beaten as an American IPA. The other beers Im having tonight come close, but not close enough.

Very aromatic and balanced with pure aromas of fresh picked citrus, hops, navel oranges, and some florals.

Medium bodied with a very good smooth feel. Balanced with very good depth, but slightly clipped on the middle and back end with very good flavors of fresh picked citrus, navel oranges and some hops.

12 oz. bottle pours a slightly hazy orange/amber with frothy white head and good lacing.  Aroma is a wonderful mix of floral and earthy hops with a malt backbone.  Taste is both sweet and bitter with a long clean and dry finish.  Medium body, velvety mouthfeel without too much carbonation.  Better than I expected, and one of my favorite IPAs.
Light citrus, with a bit of hoppy bitterness at the end.  Easy to drink, but still has something to it as well.

355 ml bottle courtesy of Sara (non-RB). Pours clear pale amber / golden with a rather big bubbly and frothy white head that slowly dissipates while leaving lots of trace on the glass. Smell is sweet and hoppy with caramel, plums, grapes, peaches, pineapple, hay, tropical fruit popsicle, pine, passion fruit, orange peal, wet soil and mango. Taste is sweet and bitter with lemon hard candy, peaches, pineapple, lemon zest, caramel, grass, pine, red grapefruit juice, unripe mango, orange zest, wet soil and hints of alcohol. Mouthfeel is round, tiny oily bitter, balanced and medium bodied. Finish is tiny sweet and bitter with grass, pine, orange peal, lemon peal, unripe mango and caramel. Nice and balanced but I must confess I expected more.

Had on draft.  Not a lot of super strong hop aromas and tastes, instead it was more well balanced flavors of pine, citrus, and floral notes.  Copper color.  Overall a very enjoyable brew that I will have again.

Poured with a thin white head, decent lacing, over a hazy yellow-amber body. Aroma is floral and earthy hops over a crackerlike malt backbone. Flavor is a fantastic balance of earthy hops and crackerlike malt, with a lingering earthy hop bitterness in the finish. Body is medium-plus, with a velvety soft carbonation. Alcohol is exceptionally well-hidden. Easily one of my favorita American Pale Ales.

Dark golden color, 3/4" thick off white head which has good retention and then clings to the sides of the glass nicely. Aroma is pine needles and clover. Taste has a nice full hoppiness which is more prounounced , and lingering towards the end, although you get hops right away as well. Grassy flavors, citrus peel, cloves/spice. Fresh and alive, does not have roasted tastes or much malty sweetness. Good for a hot day. Has a wave of smoothness throughout, I would serve this to people who say they dont like ales or hoppy beers, Even though it is full of hops flavor. Good transition beer from lager, has pilsner like dryness and crispness.

5 oz draft sample. Pours a hazy orange with a white head and nice lacing. Aroma is grapefruit, grass, and tangerine. Taste is grapefruit, oranges, and tropical fruit. Mouthfeel is medium and lightly sticky. No alcohol present. Good session ipa.
