UPDATED: AUG 24, 2007 Looks and smells like an IPA should.  Sparkling copper color with a nice foamy head.  Aroma is citrusy hops with a touch of grapefruit.  A clean flavor with citrus and  a nice bitter finish.  Very well balanced, flawless IPA.

Re-rate - I made Stone IPA a 5 because its the one beer in the world I cant live without.  This one is right behind and deserves this high rating, IMO.
Great pour. Batch #7614, packaged 9.6.2006, enjoyed 10.4.2006. Scents of pine,mild citrus, and a little campfire. Wonderfully drinkable; snappy on the tongue, while still being smooth and clean.
This is the best smelling ipa Ive ever had.  I cant quite put my finger on the aroma... definitely some citrus, but theres more.  The taste is not overpowering.  Very pleasant.
very, very good ipa, rich citrusy hops, great balance between malt and hops, wonderful lingering mouthfeel and aftertste, a great beer worthy of hemmingway.
user_location: The Land of Milk and Honey, Ohio, USA

text: CONTAINER VOLUME: 355mlCONTAINER TYPE: Bottle (Conditioned)FRESH: Consumed 1 month after productionPURCHASED @: Binnys McHenryCOST: $6.99/6-pack [SALE!]HEAD: average frothy/foamy; white; fully diminishingLACE: excellentCOLOR: Hazy light amberAROMA: Light grain; no yeast or citrus elements; heavy flower/herb/pine/spruce HOPS!MOUTHFEEL: Medium to lightPALATE: Oily coating; soft/flat natural conditioningTASTE: START- light sweet; moderate bitterFINISH- heavy bitter; long lastingCOMMENTS: Completely unbalanced!  But thats a good thing here!!! All Hops are a good thing.  Much like the DFH strain. This is the ultimate sipping brew.  Nectar of the humans!CONDITIONS: MOWING/WORKING ON CAR- n(good ANY time though)WITH FRIENDS-Y SIPPING-Quintessential! GET MY BUZZ ON- Hell, yeah!

This beer pours a dark honey brown that is slightly cloudy. The head is fluffy and a dirty brown. It fell quickly to a fluffy film. Great lacing! 

The smell is incredibly aromatic that playfully stings my nose with huge pineapple and nectarine hops. No malt detected. 

Tastes of strong pine and citrus hops with a fantastic understated foundation of oat and caramel malts. Well paired flavors! The finish is a nice sour dryness that makes me want another sip in a bad way. 

Mouth feel is full and creamy with a medium body and a little carbonation. 

Nice beer, Bells! Its not too heavy, but delicious and easy to drink!

UPDATED: AUG 19, 2014 Its everything an IPA can be, not overwrought, perfectly balanced, smart, and so soothing. Serene, sweet, and kind.  Perfect for any imagineable occasion, and quite honestly the apple of my eye. 

Cask pour at Pizzeria Paradiso, 9/15/07.  Golden, dry aroma of cantaloupe, pear juice, marginal floral tones.  Dusty flavor.  Hints of light fruits, lacking the crisp centennial bite in a vague way.  Palate takes no benefit from this particular run in the cask.  Overaged, as well.  

Tap at the Afterwords Cafe 9/19/07.  Floral grind disseminates fully and brightly in the aroma.  The hop taste is smoky, meaty and rich.  Almost perfect pleasantry.  Vanilla-kissed toffee in a balancing malt finish.  

Tap at the Afterwords Cafe 10/31/07. That comforting touch of rose essence is right out in front. 

Tap at the Happy Gnome 1/20/08.  Vibrant and fresh as can be, bursting with cantaloupe, pear, and honeydew melon soaked in the morning floral mist.   Crispy, cool, and perfect.


Fresh bottled batch on 7/1/08.  8526.  Florals have a somewhat harsh quality of leafy foliage about them, and the soft citrus and tropical fruit characters are more subdued than I prefer.

UPDATED: SEP 17, 2006 Wow...what a hoppy ale. Golden amber with staying white head. Caramel, citrus, floral and pine. Medium bodied with full flavor of orange, pine and herbs. Very hoppy. One of the best IPAs Ive had.

Pours from the bottle with a reddish copper color and a light tan head that stays with the beer nicely. The aroma is hops, the first flavor across the lips is hops, the finish is hops. But I do not feel like Ive been smacked in the face with branch of hops. The malts and carbination are there, but just enough to make overall experience very enjoyable.

Bottle.  Light golden coloring.  Front-to-back full finish with light yeast after-presence in nostrils.  Lemony but light.  Somewhat bitter but not overpoweringly so.  Sign of a good day if this is in your fridge.

Bottle poured a clear golden amber with a lasting ivory head. Aromas of carmel, floral, light pine and citrus. Palate was medium bodied and smooth. Flavors of light carmel, orange, light pine and some herbal notes with a lingering lightly bitter finish.

Pours yellow/orange with a large fluffy head. Leaves tons of lacing on the glass. Aromas of fruit and citrus, very floral hop aroma as well. Remarkably well balanced and easy to drink; a quality few IPAs can match. Sweet nose, bitter finish. Excellent IPA, great job!

Pours a golden orange.  Very dense white head that lasted forever.  Lots of carbonation.  Massive floral aroma.  Huge hops taste, hint of pine.  Lots of other very subtle flavors that work great together.  An awesome IPA.

This is another great beer from Bells Brewery!  I dont know how they accomplish being able to produce so much beer, but yet maintain such quality control.  Huge centennial hop aroma that is just great!!  Big floral and spicy notes from the hops as well.  the flavor has a nice bitterness to it that compliments the spicy floral notes of the hops.  this is an excellent example of how to brew an ipa.  Great Job to the guys at Bells in michigan.

This beer is beautifully crafted to be one of the most tasty easy drinking IPAs I have had to date. Thanks to YBSober for this beer.

Appearance: Pours a magnificent orange peach color with a huge head that lasts and lasts. Then heavy sheets of lacing decorate the glass.

Smell: Tons of fresh orange rinds. I cracked open the bottle and even before I poured the beer my wife asked (from across the room) "Is that an orange beer?" It is that bold in the initial orange citrus aroma. It settles to a perfect level of citric orange rind and sweet toasted malt.

Taste: If you have ever juiced your own oranges in a juicer you can peel off the top orange layer and leave the white rinds on the orange that you juice. It makes a more bold tart tasty fresh orange juice. This beer reminded me of that juice I used to make. My juicer is still in the attic from when we moved. I think it will stay there and I will get more of this Two Hearted Ale. Wow!

Mouthfeel: So remarkably smooth. A bit juicy with just a bit of a hop nibble keeping the medium/light body interesting. 

Drinkability: Now that I have met this beer, buy stock in Bells Brewery because I am on a quest for cases. I could drink this all day everyday. It really hits the spot and is remarkably easy to drink!

Hope this is helpful.
Cheers!

Thanks realale420 for the 12oz bottle.  I must admit, I was not expecting much from the label presentation, but as soon as I opened it I knew it was going to be a good beer.  The floral aroma from the hops is huge.  The taste is different than most IPAs, it must be the type of hops they used...any ideas?  A very balanced IPA.

UPDATED: JAN 11, 2009 Its already been said 737 times or so but here it is. A gorgeous orange color with a massively beautiful white head that lasts throughout the drankin experience. Wonderful floral hop aroma with hints of pine. Deliciously bitter with tons of fresh green hop tastes. The thing about this beer is that it slowly becomes delicious liquid adult candy as it warms. I get a noticeable candy orange taste in the background that reminds me of orange Pez candy. The sweet tangy citrus flavors totally work with the incredible bitterness to create a unique IPA experience. Great stuff.

Thanks to iowaherkeye for this one. Poured a cloudy orange body with a fairly large head and decent lacing. Aroma is very hoppy with loads of fruit, mostly grapefruit. Also some spicy hops too. Flavor is the same, good bitterness and malt backbone... balanced well. Nice, one of the best IPAs out there.
Bottle, poured almost orange with a thick coarse head.  Floral aroma.  Taste was of citrusy, spicy hops and an almost sweet malt backbone.  Very good beer.

Bottle from? I think The_Epeeist. Cloudy golden with pretty good head....Nice malty and spicy/floral hop aroma with a little bit of alcohol sweetness. The hops in this are almost unlike any other IPA Ive ever had...big floral hop taste. Similar to the Jasmine IPA by Elysian, but...nothing but hops in here, didnt need any jasmine to get this taste. Pretty good thickness. Not too alcoholic, very driankable. I could have a few of these, and would love to.
This was a fine beer. Aroma was fruity. The taste was smooth and the hop taste was of mild hops and creamy malts. Slightly thin with a mellow finish.
Very hoppy, lots of citrus and spicey pine, but still very smooth. Slight chewy sweetness in the finish. AN excellent IPA for sure.

Nice cloudy orange pour with a lasting white head.  Very flowery aroma with a bit of bready malt.   Citrus hops are more evident in the taste and there is a nice bitterness that lasts through the entire tasting experience.   This is very light on the palette but has a great depth of flavor.  The malt does back up the hopping quite well and there is a lot to love in this as a complex and flavorful session type beer.  Exceptional.  I really enjoyed the long finish.

UPDATED: JUN 23, 2008 Pours to a nice hazy-burnt orange color.  Aroma is a mixture of flowers, citrus, and light pine.  Nice citrusy hop flavor with fine malt taste for balance makes this a very good IPA.  Finish and aftertaste superb.  One of my new favorites.

Big offwhite coarse-ish head over hazy orange body with ongoing
carbonation. Deep, sweet, cookie-like malty aroma with hop notes so
harmoniously blended I cant tell what the hops are like. Taste is
deep, spicy malts with a deep, bitter resiny hop background. Peas, and
grass as well. Bitter, resiny aftertaste. Very good, but slightly
lacking in complexity. If they added just a little to this it would be
an extraordinary beer. As a session beer this would be fantastic.
(0.355l bottle, thanks to gr0ve.)

Bottle.  Poured a clear deep gold/orage with a thick off-white head.  A fruity citrus character dominates a hoppy nose.  A mouth filling rush of hops at first quickly overtaken by a fruity citric body with hints of grapefruit, orange, and lemon that add a touch of sweetness make this very full and smooth beer excellent.

I think Im a victim of circumstance. Or at least location. First of all, big thanks to moejuck, that stud of a trader. Now my dilemma. Being located in Northern California, Id say Ive got access to some outstanding APAs and IPAs. While this really is a good beer, I just dont think its an IPA. I know, I know. You say Im used to all that extreme West Coast IPA. Well, yes and no. This just doesnt have that IPA bite to it. But I digress. Aroma is malty, yes and hoppy. Theres a little caramel in the nose, but also its a bit tinny. Appearance is solid gold in color. Looks great! Mouthfeel is very full, round and yet soft. The flavor is a nice malty/hop balance with an astrignent finish. A good beer no doubt. An IPA? Hmmm...I think not.
Great IPA!  Pours hazy gold, with nice frothy head and lacing.  Bright citrus hopes with a good nose, some pine and spice and a great lingering finish that reminds you that you just had a great beer.

Hops are right there from the beginning. Tried in Northern Lower Michigan. Quickly became favorite of the week. Clear color and nice head. Finishes bitter. Limited availability, not sold everywhere that Bells other products are available, well worth looking for.
Full bodied aroma and texture. Crisp hop bite with flowing flowered body and subtle fruitly finish. My favorite IPA.

A cloudy orange/amber pour with foamy white head.  Aroma is hop driven, small amount of malts. sticky bread, and some spice.  Taste-Hoppiness is definite, light fruity notes, malt backing, light spice.  palate is very lightly carbonated, bitter, and long.  Overall this is a very nice IPA.  Definitely among the best of the style!!!

Very hazy gold color with an off-white head that laces well.  Very typical IPA but well made and well balanced.  Aroma is nice and hoppy with hints of pine and citrus.  Crisp bitter hop flavor with some sweet malts balancing it out.  A great (but not terribly unique or complex) IPA.

12oz bottle poured a nice clear amber/orange with a good lasting off white head. Aroma was big citrus hops with nice noticeable sweet malts. Taste had a smooth citrus bitterness with great balance of malts. Great IPA with nice balance.

On Tap @ The Griffin in Battle Creek.  Pours amber/auburn clear with a nice head and lacing.   Hop flavor is very well balanced mix of bitterness and mild sweetness.   not a heavy IPA - it has earthy flavors which dont overpower, pine flavor and citrus.  The aftertaste lingers for a while, and is memorable.   Smooth with minimal carbonation.

Bottle:Cloudy gold color with a large fluffy off-white head that lasts all the way to the end.  A good majority of sticky lacing is pasted to the inside of the glass as well.  Typical hoppy aromas of juniper, pine and citrus.  The tastes shows sweet floral notes followed by citrus rind bitterness.  It is a smooth drink and a bit thin for an IPA, but quite classic for the style.  Loved it!  Thanks Santa.
Not a bad little IPA pours and smells like you would expect. It even has all the flavor of a decent IPA mouthfeel is a little thin. Good stuff and I will buy again but not amazing.

Good deep orange body with a large frothy off-white head.  Aroma is of pine, citrus, with light vanilla overtones. Flavor is excellent for an IPA, hoppy and bitter, with a nice malt compliment.  Excellent springy ending.  Big thanks to brentfeesh for sending this to me as part of his "recovery" plan.  =)
Hazy gold colour, insane amounts of pine aroma.  Hoppy!  Very nice.  Clean, crisp, deliciously bitter.  I approve.

UPDATED: MAR 24, 2009 On tap at Bottoms Up Pizza on 02/10/2009. Clear golden body with a medium creamy off-white head. Sweet citrusy and resiny hop aroma with some caramel notes. Sweet citrus hop flavor with some caramel and a resiny background. Medium full body with moderate carbonation. 8/3/9/4/17 - 4.1

08/02/2006: Hazy amber color with a large creamy off-white head. Sweet floral hops aroma. Sweet citrus hops flavor, some hints of vanilla.  8/5/9/4/17 - 4.2

I was shocked when I noticed I had not rated this one - Ive had many since Ive been rating.  Pours hazy amber with a nice sized white head with nice lacing.  Hops hit hard on the aroma - lots of citrus and floral qualities.  Malt is apparent to give some balance.  Fuller body than most IPAs and a good deal of frothy smooth carbonation.  Starts off with a huge amount of floral hops and rich malt to balance them.  Bits of woody hops are in the mix also.  Then comes a prickly pinecone sensation from the carbonation and citrus / piney hop aspect.  Excellent IPA.

Golden amber appearance with slight head retention and attractive lacing.  Large nose, showing floral notes and sweet hops.  Full crisp mouthfeel, well-balanced hop profile, grapefruit and minerals, ending in a medium, clean finish.  Very enjoyable IPA.

Hazy golden IPA with a thick creamy white head. Floral C-hops with nutty maderized malt in aroma. In mouth, a fragrant IPA with earthy citrus, a biscuitty malt, light mint notes, lingering hops covering the mouth. A very nice IPA from a trade with Piscator, Nov. 2005.

I love this ipa.  i can always buy and never be disappointed.  Aroma is west coast hop with some pale malt underneath.  Flavor is beautiful sweet citrus, very orange.  Finish is a nice dry bitterness.  There are no holes in this taste solid all the way.  Everything i want in a base IPA.

bottle.  batch 7397.  Aroma:  Hops grab hold of my nose and dont let go.  Citrus (more orange than grapefruit).  A nice floral aroma thats more fresh flowers than perfume or potpurri.  Also getting a great piney aroma reminiscient of walking through an old-growth pine forest.  Fresh and clean.  Underneath all that is a sweet malt aroma that peeks out invitingly.  Appearance:  Light orange and hazy.  Head was white and huge.  Lingered a good long time, too.  Nice lacing.  Flavor: Orange, honey, spice, and floral hop flavors all come through together.  The maltiness in the middle is moderately sweet with notes of caramel.  The bitterness is good, not too agressive but does its job.  Getting some nice grass notes in the aftertaste.   Palate: medium-light bodied.  Moderate carbonation.  Finish was medium dry.  Some alcohol warming on back of tongue.  Overall:  A great IPA and easy to drink to boot.  Everything works together well.
Two hearted bells is a good.  I always compare which I know I should not do but it is not as tasty as the Stone IPA or Titan IPA good but Bells has better beers.

Bottle courtesy of Daalamar: Poured a light orangey color ale with a huge foamy head with great retention. Aroma of floral hops is quiet enticing with a great semi-sweet malt base. Taste of crisp and citrus hops are well mixed with a nice solid sweet malt based. Carbonation is lively and body is about average. Overall a really good example and enjoyable take on the style thought a bit overrated in my opinion.

Once again, this just makes me frustrated that I cant get Bells in my area. Smell is incredible, looks so clean and pure, and that great hoppy taste is delicious. Flavor isnt anything unexpected, its just done perfectly. Having had this and the Stone IPA in the same week, I am in hop heaven.

Yum.  I would have never figured trout to taste so damn good.  Hop lovers rejoice.  This fits the bill and then some.  What really caught me by surprise was the incredibly clean, almost dry, finish.  I know Ive said it time and again, but if they sold this here in my neck of the woods, this would be my go-to beer.  Plus, the label is great.  Fish.  On a beer bottle.  Corny or genius?  You decide.  Courtesy of Naven, Divine Devotee as of 7/21/06.

Golden pour with an ever so faint haze and topped by a medium off white head settling to a fine bubbly layer. Big hop aroma of pine, citrus with some faint floral notes. There is also some light toffee noticeable. Rich, medium/full mouthfeel with a fine, light carboantion. There is a nice malty base of sweet caramel balanced by wonderful grapefruit  bitterness. Finish is lightly astringent with a prolonged bitterness. This is a terrific IPA, among the very best that Ive had.

UPDATED: FEB 11, 2007 Thanks to Styles for this one.  What an incredible beer.  The aroma was of wonderful grapefruit pine and flowers.  Pours an off orange color with a nice off white head.  Taste of extremely smooth and palate was bitter and malty.  I wish I had more of these, what a wonderful beer.

UPDATED: JUL 31, 2008 pours hazy medium orange with a off-white head.  Aroma is lightly malty of cookies and carmel, heavily hoppy of grass, pine, grapefruit, lemons and flowers, moderatly yeasty of bubblegum, peach and pears.  Flavor starts balanced tword the bitter side, but with a nice malty backbone, green complex hops profile, finishes heavily bitter.  Medium bodied, creamy and softly carbonated.

Mateo, mi esposo ha traido toda una pequeña seleccion de cervezas y cada una es mejor que la otra. Esta es una delicia tambien, va super bien con la comidas bien sazonadas y sobre todo va rebien con un baño de burjujas, unas velas y un poco de musica....que buena cerveza!

An enormous pine-scented hop aroma sets the stage.  The ale pours cloudy light amber with visible hop lace and some viscosity.  Pacific Northwest hops produce pine, floral, and cilantro-like flavors.  The malt and yeast components are very clean but nondescript.  The hops finish very long with citrus-peel astringency.

UPDATED: MAR 4, 2008 12 oz. bottle via trade with hippie4beer -  Pours a slightly hazy golden color with a thin off white head.  Light lacing and carbonation.  Has a floral, pine, and light citrus hop aroma.  Has a sweet, almost berry like hop flavor.  Has a faint astringent aftertaste.  Medium to full body.  A very good beer.  Thanks Seth.

Pours a pale amber color, with a nice white frothy head. Good, floral-hop aroma. The flavor is a great mix of sweet citrus, pine and bitter hops. This has a solid body, but not too thick for an IPA. Overall, a delicious brew.

UPDATED: FEB 29, 2008 Bottle. Sweet hoppy aroma. Generous head that thins but stays, pale complextion. Flavor is well balanced with malt and hops. Slightly bitter and sweet. Light carbonation. Good taste on the tongue. Good IPA. Cheers!

12 oz bottle thanks to Santa.  Orange pour with a beautiful head.  Faded to a decent lace-forming ring.  Aromas were very floral, and very sweet citrus, sweet pineapple, some vanilla.  Malt came through quite a bit more in the flavor.  Citrus still in the hoppy finish, some nuttiness too.  Very good

12 oz bottle.  Clear orange with a snow white head.  Fresh mandarin orange nose with a whisper of maraschinos.  A little pina colada gets musty.  Starts clean, light and floral.  Under-ripe peach and golden raisins.  Flavors a little thin.  Develops mild bitterness with some citrus returning.  Delicate but delicious.

An upper-end IPA in my book.  Hops flavor is strong, but blends smoothly into the citrus/pine flavors and is smoothed out somewhat (not too much) by the woodsy/oaky malt undertones.  Great finish - bitter, yet refreshing.

Bottle at Arts Tavern, Glen Arbor, Michigan.  Pours with ambient waves of wheat yellow and nice lacing.  Aroma is orange, pine, and sour citrus.  Flavor is a nice mixture of sweet grapefruit and subtle pine undertones.  Palate lays the flavors on thick.  A very well-made IPA; balanced almost perfectly.
user_location: Ugly, Hot, and Humid Spring, Texas, USA

text: Had this one bottled at Lunar in Villa Park, Illinois.  Deep golden pour with a light tan head, slightly cloudy, with a very pronounced hop nose, plenty of hops and roses in the taste.  Excellent IPA.
Pours a nice ambeer/orangeish color with a nice white head.Great citrusy/Piney hop aroma to it.Big piney followed by a citrus hop flavor.Nice bitter ending.Great Brew!

Prototypical delicious IPA.  Extremely floral nose,  with grapefruit and clean pine.   Ample malt to balance the hops and provide a great body.   Caramelly hop mouthfeel and a satisfying intense finish.

To me the aroma is sorta pine-y, like Upper Michigan along the Two Hearted. Ive tried at least 10 different great IPAs and this is my favorite of all. Two Hearted is complex, amazing, and a gracious example of really good beer to be simply enjoyed anywhere. Reminds me of camping in the U.P on the Two Heart.

pours brown/ orange. creamy off-white head. aroma is wonderful with citrus and spice. thick mouth feel, but not too much body. great oak and piney hop flavors. perfect balance of hops and malt. my personal favorite beer

I usually dont get into IPAs like others I know, but this one is an exception.  You dont have to get ready for this brew - know what I mean?  It pours easy and drinks easy.  Not too watery and a fine aftertaste.  The beer is crisp and the citrus aspects are tough to ignore.  A fine brew.

Bells Two Hearted is one incredible IPA. The pour is dark brown with some orange color mixed in. The head is considerable, but who cares about looks when these aromas are calling your name? The citrus hops are awesome, and call to your senses in every way. The mouthfeel is so nice and thick for an IPA, that you just have to love it. I really enjoy the malt backbone in this brew. The hops are playing electric guitar, but the malt is laying down a solid beat in the background. A great balance of both for sure. With so much flavor, Bells Two Hearted has to be on your priority list if you have yet to enjoy it."

Still catching up on the beers I got from the_Epeeist in trade. Thanks! Almost no head, what there is, is white and disappears immediately. Certainly not a West Coast IPA. I almost think there should be a new category of IPAs for the SoCal IPAs, but that might put the purists off a little too much. SD IPAs have a truckload more malt than this, and an obvious overload of hops. There is a crisp hop finish to be sure, and an exceptional balance when it comes to flavor and in the nose. An expertly crafted IPA without doubt. Yet, as a resident of San Diego, I cannot help but wonder if the makers of this beer would have been influenced on the hop-side by what is going on around here. My personal struggle is that my introduction to IPAs came here, in San Diego, where the hop load is in the opinions of most, entirely too much. Im working on that, and I think this beer is incredible. Balanced. Orange. Crisp. Perfect, no matter where you are in the US.

UPDATED: SEP 17, 2008 Pours orange yellow with medium head, decent lacing. Very nice orange and grapefruit aroma. Sweet flavor, some bitterness comes through in the finish. Smooth mouthfeel. Very good, complex beer.

This is a yellow orange, almost golden colored beer with a small white head.  It smelled like fresh juicy oranges with a lot of hops and some floral notes.  In the flavor there is some grapefruit and sweetness, along with the big hops and malt, and its such a clean and crisp yet full and well balanced flavor that its hard to say anything bad about this beer.

On draught, a standard orange yellow with a decent head, maybe a slight haze, but nothing particularly promising looking.  On the other hand, incredible promise in that smell.  A sweet sticky hop jamboree alongside a big beefy malt bonanza.  Citrus, dominated by tangerine and grapefruit, and huge well rounded malt.  The mouthfeel is smooth, theres great stickiness, and perfectly appropriate CO2 levels.  The taste is truly exceptional.  Everything in the aroma is here in the taste (though perhaps not the tangerine).  Theres big grapefruit and sticky piney hops over a rich and smooth malt backbone.  Tonight this beer was particularly fresh and juicy, though I dont think this could ever get lower than a 4.0 from me (or anyone in their right mind).  Really something special, I love this beer.
Nice citrus flavors up front.  Pours a deep orange color with big foamy white head.  Malty, piney, wood aromas.  Slightly sweet with a good balance between the malt and hops.

UPDATED: JAN 14, 2008 An amazing beer. Pours with a long lingering off white head. A hazy orange color with amazing fresh taste, great hops but extremely well balanced, a bit tiny bit of sweetness to match the hops. Lots of citrus tones in this one, which helps my scoring. This is a serious extremely complex beer, and I think might be my all-time favorite.  Incredible.

12oz bottle: bottle conditioned, as far as i can tell from the sedimentation at the bottom-and the flavor to match.  lots of malt and lots of hops, and i mean lots of hops. good though, seems like more than 6% in strength, but just a very well brewed beer.  Now Ill have to try Bells other brews while Im out here..
Golden color, strong floral aroma.  A little malty, with a hoppy finish.  I am not always a big fan of IPAs, but really enjoy this beer.  A personal favorite.
tap@ brewery.  Nose is piney with lemon grass notes.  Flavour is strong with cascade. there is a light roasted charasteric.  Mouth is barely chewey with a pleasant floral aftertaste.

Bottled. Thanks to BeerandBlues2 and Ernest for sharing. Beer is a hazy medium copper with a large, white, frothy, mostly lasting head. Nice wings of lacing on the sides of the snifter. First impression on the nose is that of balance and woodsyness. The aroma is malty with moderate notes of toasted grain, cookie and caramel; Hoppy with a balanced portfolio of moderately-weighty grapefruit, herb, straw, resin/pine and cedar, trace of marigold flower; Yeasty with a light note of dough, trace of sharp cheese; Miscellaneous notes of powdered ginger, perhaps a trace of white pepper and tropical fruit. The flavor is moderately sweet, moderately bitter, lightly acidic with a long, moderately acidic, moderately sweet, lightly bitter/grippy finish. The body is medium, the texture is velvety and the carbonation is lively. Neat-o

UPDATED: SEP 18, 2016 Bottle (Aug 30, 2016 bottling).

Head is initially average sized to large, frothy, white, mostly lasting.
Body is light amber.

Aroma is lightly to moderately malty (toasted grain, cookie), moderately hoppy (grapefruit, apricot, resin, orange), with a light note of dried mango.

Flavor is moderately sweet, lightly to moderately acidic, lightly to moderately bitter.
Finish is lightly to moderately sweet, lightly to moderately acidic, moderately to heavily bitter.

Medium body, velvety texture, lively carbonation.

Probably the freshest bottle Ive had, and not surprisingly also the most resinous smelling bottle too. A few more months of age will likely help, given that its bottle conditioned...hopefully soften the flavor balance a bit, ease back on the resin, and bring out more ester nuances.

Hazy golden color with a large white head.  Huge floral aroma with some nice pine notes.   Pine/citrus more noticeable in the flavor with a valiant attempt by the malt to add some balance.  Very flavorful and drinkable ale.

UPDATED: NOV 10, 2006 The hops were so arromatic at first it reminded me, unfortunately, of some flowery air deoderant/bag but I quickly sensitized and now I crave the aroma. Fantastic dry balanced hop flavor if you are in the mood for smoothness. Once or twice ive had a bottle that seems a bit off, and I dont think its me-- apparently perfection  is hard to achieve 100% of the time.

UPDATED: AUG 21, 2006 Aroma is a kiss of sugar sour apple hops.  Looks a deep amber gold, small fine white tight hed with sponge cake bubbles.  Bitter, a little fruity, not too complex, a little over-bitter masking any potential flavor.  Slightly metallic palate.  Not to my taste for IPAs.
Re-rate: nice juicysweet citrus aroma.  Pilsnery pale gold with whitecap head.  Tastes like a big sweet orange with a mild , smooth, creamy hop finish.  Moderate-light alcohol presence.  Overall a better flavor, palate and experience than my first drink, but still not a top experience, a solid IPA without major flaws.

Tasted from bottle at Nat. Homebrew Conference 06/23/06. Golden color with white head. The aroma was strong and all hops. I could smell floral and an orange citrus note. The flavor was all hops too. It tastes just as it smells. Nice round hop flavor cut with some citrus hop bitterness. Really nice beer.

355 ml bottle. Yellowish golden. Clear. Throws a tall creamy white head that clings to the glass. Pungent slightly sweet raspberry hop aroma. Great aroma that makes you want to throw it down immediately. Medium-bodied. Feels slightly sweet in the mouth. There are lots of hops that counteract those hops to make it a well-balanced one. Hoppyness is really mellow and the bitterness is without harsh notes. Finishes somewhat abruptly with a watery feeling. This is a great IPA. Batch 7355.

Pours to a hazy golden-orange, with off-white head and excellent lacing. Aroma is strongly hoppy, mostly floral and grass, with a hint of citrus. Flavor is much the same, with just the right amount of hop bitterness. Beer ends with a dry finish. All and all, a very enjoyable IPA.

UPDATED: JUL 10, 2015 Bottle, batch 7397. Bought at brewery. This is my first 5 rating after 143 reviews. Complex smell and taste with bitter, sweet and fruit. Im a big fan of Founders and Stones---but this is the best IPA!

16 ounce can. Two weeks old and BALANCED are the keys! Not the highest IBU, but the smoothest IPA in MI.

UPDATED: SEP 18, 2013 Pours clear straw golden with medium fluffy white head.  Aroma is big floral and citrus hops with a hint of bready malt.  Taste is floral and grassy hops upfront with some sweet bready malt on the follow through.  Aftertaste is lingering bitter citrus hop notes.  Palate is medium with some stickiness.  Overall an excellent IPA with great balance with big hop flavor offset by nice touches of malt.

Batch 7245.  Pours a slighty hazy golden amber with an average foamy off white head that left some lacing.  Excellent floral and citrus hop aroma with just about the right caramel malt balance for what I look for in a great IPA aroma.  Flavor of pine, grapefruit, slight malt sweetness along with a medium hop bitterness.  One of the better IPAs Ive had for sure.

12-oz. bottle, Batch 7237 from tjthresh.  Pours a slightly cloudy bronze, brass with a medium frothy white head, diminishes somewhat to a patchy film, some lacing.  Aroma is very fragrant floral and citrus hops, perfumey, caramel malt (meal, grain, straw), slightly toasted, yeast (dough).  Moderately bitter and medium acidity, tart hop rind, pine juice, malty balanced flavor with a hint of oranges.  Medium bodied, fizzy and dry palate.

UPDATED: JUN 26, 2006 Poured an orange color with a huge pillowy head and great lacing. Took three pours to get it in, while waiting for the head to settle. Sedimentation came out on the last pour(s) and remained separated out, like a black and tan: two phase beer, cloudy sedimentation cloud on top. The aroma was nice, hoppy, some pine, some citrus. The flavor was strongly hopped, some bitter malts underneath, including caramel. Some bitter citrus rinds and some pine hops. The mouthfeel was typical for the style with a fairly heavy body.

Nice clear beer.  If you dont pour the settled yeast from the bottom of the bottle into your glass.  Nice Citrus aroma.  It doesnt taste like fish on the bottle but goes great with a fish dinner.  One of the best IPAs I ever had.
UPDATED: AUG 26, 2006 Im a novice but this was pretty good beer.   citrus, orange, hazy, medium sweetness, lightly bitter, medium body, creamy, average carbonation,

UPDATED: DEC 22, 2006 First time on tap at old chicago and it wasnt that good because old chicago, Eden Prairie DOESNt CLEAN THEIR LINES!
But from the bottle we get the goods:  Pours a mostly clear dark orange with a nice medium pillowy white head that stays.  Big floral, perfumy hop aroma with a little sweet malt background.  
Floral, pine and grapefruit hit u up right of the bat then a nice malt kicks in the middle leaving a light bitterness in the back of the pallete.  Medium bodied on the pallete.

Hemingway-esque trips?  A nice thought.  Had a couple of these the other night with dinner.  Nice tasting IPA.  Not quite as hoppy as I expected.  And call me shallow, but the label threw me off a bit.  Would drink it again.  BAsed on cbrixiuss review, I would like to try the Draft version.

Fantastic beer.  Had it on draft at the Brewhouse Grille in Camp Hill, PA.  Could smell the Cascade hops from a mile away, similar to Stone IPA and Troegs Nugget Nectar in character and taste.  Had it last year in a six pack but not as memorable as the draft.

UPDATED: JUN 5, 2010 I’ve been thirsty for this brewer ever since I signed up here. And FINALLY I make it to Detroit for the Movement music fest and just so happen to come along to a place called Jacoby’s that had a Bells product. The previous night I was left high and dry when i got to the club too late and they already stopped serving...sooo I missed out on the stout. Anyhow. VERY FINE IPA. Complex yet subtle in every degree. From the hoppy malt nose to the hop-in-the-kitchen taste. Very refreshing and clean and well blended. Some tartiness here, some sweetness there. Each sip was different. Fruits to Grasses. TECHNO AND BEER!!  Because I miss this so much, it gets a 5.

Bottled. Pours a hazy light amber with a substantial yellow-white head with plenty of lace. The aroma is citrus and tropical fruit, with the smallest hint of pine. Medium body with medium carbonation. The nicely rounded taste starts sweet, with oranges, bread, apples, honey and toffee. The IPA-level hops finally show up in a bitter aftertaste. This is a really tasty, absolutely sessionable beer, but I have a hard time seeing it as an IPA.
On trade from sliffy.  From bottle pours a cloudy light orange with thick white head.  Nose is piney with a hint of floral.  Flavor follows with a crisp, bitter finish.  Very drinkable IPA.
12 oz bottle courtesy of gputty. Hazy, dirty yellow pour with a white head. Mostly floral nose, some grapefruit notes. Smooth, medium bitter. Nice, but I dont get the hype.

Clear, orangey-gold, nearly white head.  Very, very nice peachy-plum fruity aroma -- like when you open your produce drawer and youve got some fruit thats about to get over-ripe.   Robust AIPA flavor, diacetyls, caramel, pine, mildly briney.  A mature pint.  Finish is medium and the hops dont cling.  Buttery at times.  Better as it warms.  Excellent.
A great session IPA.  Not overwhelming but distinctive.  I was a little put-off at first by the thin gold color, but the flavor is full with a satisfying feel to the mouth.

Best damn IPA.  The Two-Hearted has a viciously hopped aromatic bouquet.  The flavor is balanced like freight-train and crisp like the autumn air.  The bouquet reveals itself on your bitter ridge taste buds sending G-force quivers down your palates fault line.  This intense IPA splashes smoothly down the throat with a fluffy, creamy head.  Plenty of swirling sediment adds to its robust, flawless character.

The hoppy aroma immediately brings to mind sugary flowers. Orange/tangerine notes rush forward as well. The color is dark gold with with a smaller white head. The mouthfeel is exceptionally full and delicious. The flavor is of course the main attraction. More citrus on the tongue, really kind of bitter but like any IPA. This is the IPA to measure against all others.

This is the finest IPA Ive ever tasted.  It is so well made and such a refreshing change from the "sledgehammer" IPAs that dominate the market.  The aroma is reminiscent of hop perfume, absolutely perfect.  The appearance can be a little cloudy, just age in the fridge for a week and pour straight out with no gurgling.  The flavor just sings with American hops and a great malt backbone.  Bitterness is just right.  So well made and so well balanced, I dont know how they do it.  A definite must try.
Pours hazy gold with thin quicy disipating head.  Excellent floral hop aroma.  Smell slightly sweet.  Taste is bitter hops.  Slightly warm crisp finish.  Excellent IPA.
Very tasty beer. Some hop, more on the sharp side, but not overwhelming.  Very pleasant scent.

Bottle at Coles. Ive been craving a nice IPA lately and once I saw this on the bottle list at Coles I knew this wouldnt dissapoint. Poured a hazy amber body with a medium creamy head. Great floral, big hoppy aroma. Great, well balanced hops and malts. Some cherry flavors. I really wish this was available in NY, awesome beer.
This is a wonderful beer that can be consumed all year round. I love the crisp floral hopsy taste. Strong notes of chamomile (?). Tastey and refreshing.
Pours reddish-yellow with off-white head.  Strong citrus malt aroma, with a well developed hoppy flavor.
UPDATED: MAR 22, 2007 Bottle. Poured a nice red-yellow type color. Decent amount of head, but it did disappear in a semi-quick manner. Flavor and smell were citrusy. This was hoppy and good.
Very good.  This beer could pass for any west coast IPA.  Pours a nice bronz-ish color.  The smell is amazing.. Very floral, hoppy.  This is a damn good IPA.
Usually, I go for the darker orange, cloudy IPAs. This one has a lighter color, but is brewed by Bells, so what the hell, huh!?! Good citrus/nutty flavor, but leaves me wanting for some reason....

Solid. Poured an orange color with a nice fluffy head and solid lacing. Aroma was pine and citrus Flavor was bitter, pine hops and citrus. Hops were done well though not overbearing. Mouthfeel was a little heavy"

On tap at richos - Pours a hazy copper with a creamy ivory head. Lots of draping lace down the side of the glass. Smells of cirtusy hops and light fruity malt. Taste is dominated by intense floral and citrusy hops. Theres some light pale malt crispness in there but this brew is all about the hops. And while the beer may be unbalanced the hops flavors are nicely balanced with each other. Bitter and sweet citrus intertwined. Long lingering bitter aftertaste and crisp. Taste leaves you craving more. Good stuff.

UPDATED: APR 26, 2006 On draft at Issac Newtons with Stegosaurus. Pours hazy golden with a white head. Aroma of pine, hops, citrus, and sweet malts. Flavor is carbonated fruity, citrusy, sweet malts and a bitter finish. Too hoppy for me.

Pours a somewhat hazy golden orange with a off white head with decent retention. The aroma is full of both citrus and pine and perhaps a bit of light malt. The flavor is also dominated by the citrus/floral hops combo with a little bit of light sugar torwards the front. Smooth with a sturdy body that leads up to the bitter hop ending...all very fluid and balanced. This beer is a no brainer if you like the style and could certainly work as a awesome Summer session beer. Easy to enjoy and pairs really well with blackened catfish dinners.
UPDATED: APR 30, 2006 Very hoppy, but very well balanced. citrusy with a dry finish. Bells makes great beer and this is easily one of the best they make. This has become my favorite IPA hands down

Tried this beer as a rec from Bon.  Not disappointed in the least!  Huge, sharp, hoppy nose that declares its IPA tag from the first pour.  Very full taste fills up your mouth with every sip.  Suprisingly potent, a six pack will get you to where you need to be.

Bottled, thanks heemer77. Hazy orange colour, mediumsized beigeish head. Aroma is caramel, fruits and hops, enormous nose! Flavour is pleasant and smooth fruity hops with also wheat, a bit yeast and caramel. Very pleasant IPA, one of the best so far. Creamy smooth palate.

Bottled 
Hazy orange, good steady creamy white head, some lace. Fabulous citrus and pinewood hoppy aroma. Good malty backed with lemony hops. Fruity finish, a bit yeast also in the flavor. I liked aroma more than flavor.
A delicious IPA with heavy citrus and hop notes. Truly one of the best (if not the best) IPAs ive had. Very strong hops, but not overpowering, with a a tasty citrus flavor. Highly recommended.
Nice Orange pour with a huge head. Nice hops in this one.... Citrus is nice in this one, aftertaste sits well on the tongue. A good beer to drink after doing my taxes! thanks to Duane for this Gem!

Pours an amber-orange hue with a tight, creamy and durable white head. Had one of the freshest hop aromas of any beer Ive ever sampled. As a homebrewer it reminded me of the burst of hop aroma when you first open a vacuum sealed bag of freshly harvested hop flowers. Lots of lemony/orange citrus notes in the aroma. Palate was smooth and light. Flavors were nicely balanced between the lightly toasted malts and the citrusy hops. Found the finish to be a bit tame and quick, but overall a well made, solid American IPA.

UPDATED: OCT 3, 2007 Pours and orangish copper with a white head. Had floral and citrus aromas. The flavor was very hoppy and citrusy but did not leave a bitter aftertaste which was nice. Was a great IPA.
Pours amber with a fluffy white head that has good lacing.  The aroma is very hoppy.  The flavor is very well balanced with hops, but not overbearing and a citrus taste.  This is a very good beer.

UPDATED: AUG 6, 2006 Wonderful floral hop aroma. Pours out with a nice bubbly and slighly lacy head... slight haze to the fine deep gold colour. The flavor is heavily hopped (as would be expected of an IPA), sweet mild fruity tones, very inviting for the next taste. A hair bit on the bitter side for the aftertaste but overall an excellent IPA..
Floral hoppy scent. Hazy color to it. Has a light bubbly and lacy head. Bitter aftertaste. Very pleasent IPA one of the best I have had.
im not a huge pale ale fan, but there is something about this one that sets it apart, i enjoyed the flavor.
Slighty hazy orange with a small white head.  Smells and actually tastes a bit like oranges.  Very refreshing.  Floral, but not too piney.  Good beer, maybe a tad over-rated.

Pours a clear yellowish-orange color with a thick off-white head.  Strong grapefruit aroma on this one with huge hops complimenting the grapefruit.  Flavor is very strong on the grapefruit, maybe almost too much.  Finishes off with hops that linger on the palate for awhile.  Still a very delicious IPA.

UPDATED: APR 6, 2006 My first India Pale Ale! Has a very fruity, banana scent. Excellent to sup with. A fresh, fruity , and herbal (?) orange taste to it with a zing at the end. It does have a nostalgic taste to me! It reminded me of orange-flavoured medicine syrups I used to take when I was younger (no wonder I got better real quick!)! A highly recommended IPA! A special thanks to my friend and drinking mate Adam M. for the bottle!

Great IPA, one of the best.  I had it in a bottle, but Ive had it on draft and even on hand-pull at the wonderful Berkeley Front.  I would recommend this beer in any form.  Nice bitterness to it, wonderful floral smell, and very drinkable if youve had experience with bitter beers.  Not for the faint of heart, but I guess thats why its called two-hearted?
This is a perfect iteration of an IPA. Finish is smooth. Hops are abundant and aromatic. An ideal brew for almost any occaision.
I absolutely loved this beer.  A unique flavor that Ive never tasted before.  Not like any other IPA.  Oranges and Flowers.  A new favorite.
Amber/copper. Frothy, off white head. Huge, full spectrum hop nose- citrus, floral, pine, and resin. Perfect amount of malt to match. Same flavor. Balanced, medium body. Excellent IPA.
Poured into glass out of bottle.  Nice orange color.  So smooth I dont ever want to stop drinking it.  One hell of an IPA.

First, this is one of the few beers Ive had both on tap and bottle. Tap is so so so much better. On to the beer: amber nice carbonation. Lots of grapefruit on the nose and tongue. Intense citrus bitterness is bigger than the sweet sugary sweetness, but is well balanced. Lingering bitterness is pleasant and not at all overpowering. One of my favorite IPAs.
nice  orange hue to it, fine fresh hop aroma, fairly strong carbonation.  Nice refreshing bitter hop flavor.  A solid example of an IPA.

UPDATED: JUN 29, 2007 On draft at Issac Newtons. Pours hazy golden with a decent sized white head. Aroma of pine, hops, citrus, and sweet malts. Flavor is carbonated fruity, citrusy, sweet malts and a slight hoppy bitter finish. Good body, damn good brew.

From a 12 oz. long neck brown bottle with batch number 7150, packaged on 11/22/05, and a short blurb about the AIPA on the back label. Made a good appearance, poured a hazy peach hued light amber with a foamy white head that settled into a clingy, bubbly thin lacing, good carbonation. Had a big floral and citric hop nose with whiffs of fruity esters and a faint biscuity maltiness. A crisp, semi-creamy lightish medium bodied mouth feel, good drinkability. A crisp citric hop taste upfront, a smooth, rolling hop bitterness on the tongue, a little citric rind character in the middle, a biscuity maltiness and a dry Bells yeastiness showing up towards the end and a dry, bitter finish.

Draft at Jaks Tap, Chicago.  What a nice IPA.  Clear, orange golden body with a small white head.  Aroma of grapefruit and hops.  Delightful flavor highlighted by grapefruit and hops.  Very crisp, clean palate.  Very drinkable and flavorful, an excellent IPA.

clear orange with off white head. balanced aroma of toasty malt and citrus hops. sweet light toasty malt with a nice amount of hoppy orange bitterness. medium body. refreshing carbonation. dry bitter finish. great ipa.

Like I.P.A.s? Youll love this! This beer has such flavor and drinability its amazing. Smell that citrus bouquet? That heady aroma of Orange peel and possibly corriander? Good dose of Piney hops that any I.P.A. should have. This may be my new favorite.

Bottle shared with tupalev & jerc - courtesy of tupalev. Hazy golden colour with a moderate white head. Big, hoppy aroma - lots of orange and pine - with some honey sweetness backing it up. Flavour is hoppy as hell, and undeniably unbalanced, but still damn good. Wonderful stuff!

A very refreshing IPA. Citrussy, acidic orange nose, with a touch of rose. Flavor hits up front hoppy but settles down with nice woody and tannin notes. Girlfriend says it has a taste of rose ice cream. Good stuff.

had a bottle once and wasnt too impressed.  then had it at a bar once on draft.  best draft pint ive had outside a brewery/brewpub.  golden brown color, small but thick head.  not as fruity as usual IPAs; though hoppy, more carmel/woody flavor.  will give the 6pack another try.

Pours a light hazy orange/gold.  Small head diminishes to a thin ring rather quickly leaving a bit of lacing.  Aroma is piney and citric and very inviting.  Flavour is piney, grapefruit, some pleasant sweetness.  I expected a more bitter finish I suppose. But the great aroma combines with the initial flavor and smooth, rich mouthfeel to make one want another immediately.

This beer offers an aroma of hops infused with butterscotch.  It is a cloudy gold in color with a decent white head.  This beer enters the mouth with force as it introduces the hops to the tongue.  As the bitterness subsides it fades to a smooth butterscotch taste that lingers.

Bottle. Pours a nice, golden brown color. Small white had with little to no lacing. Fruity aroma. Oranges, grapefruit. Some yeast as well maybe even a slight piney smell in there as well. Bitter bite right away. Nice and thick. Gra[pefruit was the first thought about the taste of this beer. More citrus in there some pine flavors as well. Finishes with a littel bitter of a aftertaste. Good, but not my favorite.
A VERY good American rendition of the IPA... had the citrusy and spicy green hop flavor, a good backbone of malt, slightly sweet, excellent head, and finished with a bit of a green hop bite.

Bottle.  A great IPA.  Orange/copper with a slight haze and thin creamy white head.  Aroma is not quite citrus, but more orange/orange peel with herbal hoppiness.  Well-balanced flavor tips over into a nicely bitter hop finish.  Smooth and slightly crisp mouth feel. Not as good from the bottle as it is on tap, but still one of the best IPAs out there in my book.

The head was spare and the color was orange.  It had a great aroma and it tasted a bit like an orange.  It was a bit hoppy but balanced.  It was biiter at first, but then it goes away half way through.

Bottle shared with Jerc and GregClow.  Dark hazy yellow - very hazy actually, looks like a jar of honey, small white head.  Wonderfully hoppy aroma - sweet too, honey, with fresh orange citrus and some lemon - what a wonderful unique mix. Even some alcohol.  Taste has a huge hop wallop at first - very sharp and citrus like.  A little thin in the body which makes the hops even more prominent.  Dry bitter finish.  Very nice, just a tad one dimensional.

12 oz bottle courtesy of Illinismitty.  Poured a nice cloudy amber color with a 2 finger thick off-white head.  Good head retention with nice lacing.  Aroma is very hoppy with notes of pine. Flavor is very well balanced with lots of hop bitterness complimented with some malty sweetness.  Great mouth feel with a crisp lingering aftertaste.  Definitely a top 5 IPA.  Too bad it is not sold locally.

Reddish brown with a big maly hoppy nose...very nice!!! On first taste very very sweet. Acceptable for a double IPA but way too cloying sweet for an IPA. The maltiness did not balance with the hops. Almost like they stopped the fermentation early. Could not hang with the sweet finish.

UPDATED: JUL 3, 2007 bottle - This beer pours a huge, long lasting head and has a nice aroma of floral hops.  The color is a hazy yellow-gold.  The flavor has a little malty sweetness up front, along with some pine notes, and plenty of hops from start to long, bitter finish.  Mouthfeel is medium bodied and lightly carbonated.     This is simply an excellent IPA.

Bottle. Pours a slightly hazy bubbly golden-orange with a large lasting foamy white head. Wonderful aroma of floral and citrus hops -- I keep smelling it over and over [sniff, sniff] man thats awesome. Flavours the same, juicy floral and citrus hops -- so delicious. Theres malt in the aroma and flavour as well to balance things out but this is all about the hops. Creamy mouthfeel, medium bodied. An excellent IPA, if this were available locally it would always be in my fridge as its definitely one of the best IPAs Ive ever had.

Courtesy of Illinismitty

Strong pine forest aroma. Floral aromas as well. Hazy yellow body with good head and decent lacing. Pine flavor and medium bodied. Cool and crisp on the palate and gone way to fast. Been saving this one for my birthday and today the day. Didnt disappoint cheers.

UPDATED: MAY 23, 2008 Pours a light amber with little head.  Aroma is piney and sweet.  Flavor is a hop lovers delight, with pineyness and citrus aplenty, very tart and bitter while at the same time feeling balanced and clean.  I could drink this all night.  After drinking a good deal of this, I have to say it is the benchmark of American IPAs.  Astounding!

Bottle (12oz).  Poured hazy gold, plenty of bubbles, large solid lasting foamy beige head.  Sweet hoppy aroma - pine, grapefruit, apricot, pineapple and spruce, quite sharp - plus enough malt to make note of; there was a brief rush of yeast when I popped it.  The taste is really muted - fruit and citrus/evergreen hops dominate, but are quite restrained - it does finish long, and bitter, but never aggressive; the malt is lightly toasted and also just murmurs along too.  Mouthfeel is very creamy, lightly astringent, I felt it had solid body for an IPA.  If you want a solid IPA but are reluctant to tackle the sharply high IBU Ruinations of the world, give this one a try.  Recommended.
unimpressive beer for bells standards. pours light yellow and hazy with decent head. starts off with fruity textures and ends with a bland bitterness of a generic beer.

Bottle via trade with captaincougar.  Pours a murky copper color with a big white head.  Resinous, pine and citrus aromas.  Bitter with a honey-like maltiness.  Grapefruit and grass notes.  Lingering bitter finish.

Smells floral.. hoppy... like a good IPA should... almost of pine.  Beautiful light amber coloring... Creamy head with pretty lacing.  POW!  The bitterness hits you right in the jaw.  Bitter in the front and in the back.  Too bitter for my tastes, but perfectly characteristic of the style.  I am rating this higher than I like it, mostly because I know what a good IPA should taste like, and this is it.

UPDATED: MAR 13, 2008 bottle. This has the appearance of a solid pale ale: sturdy hazy copper, nice lasting, dense head. I really enjoy the floral aroma. Its very fresh and exotic with plenty of rather pleasing outdoorsy scents. Flavor is quite well balanced between the peppery hops and smooth sweet malts, though still packs a little bit of a punch with bitterness. This is an enjoyable beer for most occassions.

[Nov 9, 2007]---


Man, this stuff is good on tap. The aroma is completely full of citrusy hops. Flavor is rich of lemon, pine, grapefruit. Malts are just present enough to attempt some kind of counteraction. Even just licking my lips after this one is bitter. Good, clean, rich IPA. Excellent.


[March 2, 2008]

Draught at Yacht Club: Pours a reddish color with a nice off-white head. Hops are all over the place on this. The bitterness cuts like a knife and adds a full citrus flavor. The sweeter side of the beer is bready and only slightly fruity. This is a no-holds-barred IPA.

Bottle. Pours rich honey color with a big fluffy white head that leaves good lacing. The aroma is smooth fruity hops with traces of wood and malt. The flavor is very well balanced. Pleasantly bitter and still quite smooth. Earthy and fruity hops mingle in a playground of mild toasty malt. Definitely a good drinkin beer.

Bottle.  Didnt know it was an IPA when I ordered it.  But, waitress said Id like it.  Aroma was a nice citrus almost pine scent.  Not knowing it was an IPA, the bitterness caught me off guard.  But, for an IPA, it wasnt that bitter. Rather light.
user_location: Peoples Republic of Athens, Ohio, USA

text: Draft on tap at Bennigans. Aroma is floral, very hoppy flavor. Dont usually like IPAs but I like this one.

UPDATED: JUL 6, 2006 Batch 7196 bottle.  Aroma of piney and floral hops, with a little bit of grapefruityness.  Smells freakin awesome.  Slight sweet malts also noted.  Hazy light golden with a small white head.  Big floral hops in flavor, with a fair amount of bitterness midway, and slight bitterness in the finish taken over with a sweet homemade bread
 maltiness.  Very well balanced for an IPA. Very softly carbonated.   Will be getting this one again!
user_location: Ocean Beach, San Diego, California, USA

text: Bottle Batch 6957   Pours a clear light orange golden with ahuge fluffy persistant white head. As is slowly recedes, the glass is still coated with lacing that is drying in place.  Like that fake frost people spray in their windows.  Aroma is quite sweet for the style, more on the citrusy side than piney.  Flavor is rather mild in the hops and the sweet light malts are mellow and soft.  Carbonation is much less than I expected after the loud HISS when I opened it and for the size of the head produced.  Very mild bitternes on the trailer and a very soft feel.  Very yummy. Thanks to Styles for setting me up with this one

UPDATED: MAY 19, 2006 Intense floral nose.  Suprising and pleasant.  Golden brown, a bit hazy.
Nice and bitter.    The hops are almost overwhelming, but are most welcomed.  Im enjoying this a hell of a lot more than I thought I would.  Rich clinging head that follows to the end.
My favorite IPA.  Better than Stone.  A golden hazy color.  Lots of centenial hops on the nose.  Awesome hop flavor and enough malt to make everything perfect.  Long bitter dry finish.  Great!
Batch # 7094.  Light brown in color.  Aroma was very floral, and somewhat fruity.   Big time hops, and somewhat bitter.   Im not an IPA fan, but its one of the better ones Ive had.
ALMOST over the top of my grapefruit threshold, but manages to toe the line.  A sparkling, brightly bitter IPA that deserves the praises heaped upon it.  Malt is clean, full of melons and toffee.

This beer was one of the highlights of the 2005 GABF. Nice copper color - hard to tell much about the head with my tiny glass. Aroma was fruity and floral. Hops throughout  with a sharpness in flavor that ended on a dry note.
This is a great beer.  Has a touch of orange taste to it.  Its one of bells finest.
pours clear yellowish orange. aroma of rich hops, and citrus fruits.  flavor of citrus and hops.  a very tastey beer.

Draft 2006 pours almost hazed gold/copper with a light white head. Bottles head is much better. Aroma is your basic ipa. medium floral hops with citrus and grapefruit. Flavor is very citrusy and grapefuit with a mild bitterness to it What a wonderful beer! And available yer round... Try them both the river and the beer. Via rainbow lodge UP michigan..

Pours a hazy gold with a small amount of head. Aroma has some hop as well as citrusy fruityness to it. Tastes of citrus, grapefruit and some hops. Has a creamy and bitter mouth to it.  Taste lingers for a while. A very nice IPA.
On draft at Dilly Deli. Cask Conditioned. Hazy orange/gold. Much milder aroma and initial flavor out of the cask, but the after taste was still there. It was really good, very drinkable.

Thanks Illinismitty!!  Pours a slightly hazy golden color with a small head and no center lacing, just a little ring by the glass.  Aroma is light and slightly fruity with a very mild hop hint.  Flavor is hoppy and slightly bitter, like a grapefruit.  Sticks to the palate and lingers.  The aftertaste didnt do a whole lot for me, but i enjoyed the beer otherwise.

UPDATED: AUG 31, 2006 12oz. bottle, slightly hazy gold/orange with a foamy white head of large bubbles that lasts. Lots of dense lacing. Intense floral hop aroma, grapefruit, pine. Flavor matches aroma, could use a bit more malt flavor.  Mouthfeel is watery and moderately carbonated. Finishes with pine, citrus and hops. Somewhat acidic.
Pours deep gold, rich head, overwhelming fresh hop aroma (but in a good way).  Taste is citrusy-floral-piney with subtle underpinning of rich malt for the perfect balance.  Mighty tasty.

12 oz bottle, via illinismity.  Pours a slightly cloudy copper with a large fluffy white head.  Sediment noted in bottle.  Big fresh floral hop aroma, spicy with tangerine and lime rind.  Malt makes itself known in the background.  Aggressively hopped but not biting.  More of a soft and intricate hop profile.  Malt still remains in the background but lays a solid foundation.  Medium bodied, with soft carbonation yields a creamy mouthfeel.  A truely good beer.

12 oz bottle.  Cloudy golden-orange beer topped with 1" of white foam.  Hop aroma just spills out of this brew, big sweet orange/pine aroma, a little bit cedary and fruity as well.  Almost tropical, but still balanced by some resiny character.  Beneath the bright, sweet hop aroma is an equally pleasant slightly earthy sweet malt character.  With all of that delicious aroma, youd think the flavour couldnt match it, but it does.  Sweet pale malt with just a kiss of caramel and bready flavours topped with strong sweet piny and grapefruity hops.  Hops arent really unusual in their profile but the execution is impeccable.  Lingering bitterness.  Very tasty brew.

Fell in love with this beer as soon I pried the top off.  The hop arroma crawled up my nose and set up camp.  Beautiful sparkling gold color witha  nice snow white head.  Crisp bite and a flavor that last leaving your tounge yearning for more!!!

My draft pour was average in appearance, but that is the only thing average about this beer. The characterisitics I liked are probably drawbacks for a true IPA afficinado. But who cares. Great big sweet citrus aromas. I really liked the balance of bitter hops and sweetness. Very nice crisp, clean finish. Yum!

12 oz bottle  Pours a cloudy gold with a cramy white head.  Mostly lastingand good lacing.  Aromas are hoppy with touches of flowers, citrus, and pine.  Taste is medium bodied with a nice consistancy and carbonation.  Has a good bitter/alcohol finish which lasts well.  A very decent IPA as expected from Bells.

Cloudy, deep golden in color with a foamy white head.  Hoppy, piney, citrusy aroma.  Grapefruity, spicey, hoppy flavor.  Very smooth mouthfeel, nice hoppy finish.  Overall an excellent IPA.  One of Bells best brews.

The aroma is citrusy with overtones of both grapefruit and orange.  The color is a cloudy orange.  Head retention is excellent, being fully lasting, and is a frothy white.  The flavor has a light hoppy bite, with a touch of grapefruit.  The finish is crisp and clean.  A nice mild India Pale Ale to introduce to someone having an IPA for the first time.

Cloudy gold appearance with nice, fluffy, duvel-esque head.  Nice smell for an IPA, although a little too sweet for my taste.  Taste is also good for the style although not nearly as "biting" as I expected this beer to be.  Least favorite aspect of this brew was the fact that there is no real lasting bitterness hanging around after sipping, it just kind of goes dull after a second or two.  I understand this could be a plus for some, especially if you drink it like a session beer, but I like my IPAs to attack the palate a little more.  Overall, this is a very good beer but did not live up to the hype Ive been reading recently.  Good IPA but not one of the best.

Deep pale straw in color, with good head and lace that sticks.  Beautiful floral hops aroma with a sweet nose.  Rich and hoppy upfront and the hops really stick with you for minutes, slight sweetness that balances perfectly.  My perfect session beer.
Robe blonde très claire surmontée dune fine mousse blanche. Arômes de malt et de houblon amérisant. Saveurs dépinette, de citron et de malt.
UPDATED: MAY 9, 2007 Fruit/Flower aroma.  Citrus hints with a heavy bitter hop taste.  One of my favorites.  Now available everywhere.

UPDATED: APR 12, 2006 What a fine IPA.  Nice cloudy orange pour..nice creamy off-white head.  Nose is big, sweet, citrusy hops...very resiny.  Medium bodied with a big hoppy flavor, very citrus fruit laden, grapefruit, tangelo....this is much better than anticipated.  Not that I thought it would be bad, I just didnt think Id love it as much as I did.  Nice malt balance in this one.  Refreshing is the word.  I must get more of this...one bottle aint near enough.

First thing to greet me in the aroma was pine, but it is followed by something soft and pleasing that Im having trouble identifying (the first thing that comes to mind with it is freshly baked yellow cake...other than that I cant identify it).  Flavor is a woodsy pine that lasts throughout and into the long finish.  Maybe a bit of alcohol too.
Very light and to the point.  Lots of hops and lots of grassy/tree type flavors.  Amazing if you can get it on tap...and easy to find in a bottle

Clear amber pour with foamy head.  Initial hops fragrance is mind-numbing and piney-strong like gin.  Flavor is very strong and bright, but cedar and spruce hoppy flavors overpower all other palate dimensions.  Abrasive for casual IPA drinkers, but heaven for the intensely-hearted drinker.

Sampling from a 2 year old cellared bottle and a fresh one side by side. The hops in the fresh bottle are bracing, too much for my liking personally. However the aged two hearted reveals true craftsmanship, with a excellent balance of malt and hops. Notes of butterscotch and dried cherries along with the grapefruit and pine that is so overwhelming in the younger version. Id drink the two year old anytime, I find the young a bit too brash for my palate.

UPDATED: MAR 13, 2007 Pours orangish golden with a thin foamy, mostly maintained tan head. Aroma of sour orange, mango, and sweet grapefruit. Taste is citrus and flowery hops. Mouthfeel is medium bodied, and slightly resinous. Delightfully smooth IPA, no aggressive bitterness. Yum.

Pours dark amber with thin white head.  Smell is wonderfully hoppy with sweet malt undertones.  Taste is piney and floral with some citrus and caramel tones.  Coats mouth and leaves a complex hop aftertaste in the mouth.  Great!

yellowish orange colored pour, white head.  standard looking ipa.  smells hoppy and malty and fruity.  taste is pretty bitter, good balance of malts, and a nice little fruity like kick to it.  simply put an awesome ipa that backs up its ratings.  probably one of the best regular ipas ive ever had. never been disappointed with bells yet.
I just didnt like this beer: too bitter.  It smelled very nice, with floral hops and grapefruit aromas.  However, for me the bitterness when I tasted it overpowered everything else.

Excellent IPA. Strong citrusy hop aroma, beautiful orange-yellow color with a great frothy white head. Flavor is citrus and pine, with a smooth sweet malt character. Extremely creamy mouthfeel really makes this brew stand out.

This was the first IPA I tasted - several years ago.  Nothing I have tasted since has topped this.  Very attractive pour.  A fairly hard hitting bitterness that is softened by a fruitiness that makes it special.  Its pricey but well worth it.  To me, this is a special brew for special times. Kalamazoo is one awesome brewer!

UPDATED: SEP 11, 2006 Pours amber with a white frothy head.  The best way I can describe the smell on this one is that it conjured up images of the nasturtium in my garden as the sun beat down on them on a hot summer afternoon.  Tastes of lavender, rosemary, sage, pine, and grapefruit.  Damn near perfect mouthfeel with a lasting bitterness that stays behind for some time.

Update: I am currently enjoying another bottle of this.  IMO the best IPA Ive ever had.  I was going to write up a re-rate, but my initial feelings on this still hold up.

UPDATED: JUN 28, 2010 Hand-pulled at Ashleys in Ann Arbor
Pours a hazy light amber with a reasonable head.
The nose is big candied grapefruit peel and spice; the flavor follows, again an almost sweet, fruity and heavily spice-like beer,. definite floral tones, a warming hint of alcohol, and of course with a long and deep bitter hop finish that leaves the mouth watering deliciously for more. It doesnt come with the devastating oily resin of many of the PacNW competitors, and for this beer, that works beautifully.

This is a first-rank IPA. Im sure Im tossing it an extra couple of points for the delight of coming on cask, but this was a wonderful beer-drinking experience. (Addendum: after a repeat on tap at Red Hawk, the 4.5 stands though admittedly it was probably a point shy on tap. In the bottle, its a different beer again, with less citrus and more malt coming through. Even there were looking at 4.2 to 4.3. Great beer.)
Further addendum March 09: cracked another bottle that someone sent me last night. I was starting to wonder if it really deserves the 4.5 I gave it. After tasting again, I think so. This is definitely 4.3 territory out of the bottle; it stands right up there with Pliny the Elder or Green Flash or any of the top IPAs, but its a more midwestern beast (is that a style?) better balanced and reminiscent of the delights at Town Hall.

Bottle again, 2/10/10. Every time I get back to Michigan and have the chance to drink another bottle, I wonder whether its really as good as I remembered. The answer is always yes. Amazing stuff, lovely fruity hop flavors. Id say I was too kind to Green Flash above; its more PtE ties with two-hearted, and Green Flash comes a decided third place.

Tap 6/10 in Atlanta. Yep, bloody solid. Its a frigging crime that Alesmith tops this one as #1 IPA.

Hazy dull yellow with a rocky firm head. Very floral and resinous aroma with some pine. Clean, sweet caramel and hop flavor. Robust in body. Lightly carbonated. Really nice, soft and nourishing yet satisfying ale.

Batch 7094,Bells has a website to decode this [email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */
A swell ipa from bells,looks goofy but
the taste is a must for the hopmeisters.

UPDATED: NOV 17, 2007 Had during a beer tasting party.  Poured copper with aroma of grassy and floral.  Taste has bitterness and ends with a long finish.  Have gone back to this many weekends as my stand-by.  Not recommended for beer cheese soup though, hops took over.

12z bottle.  7094, I guess thats the batch number?  Golden, orange hue with a slight tint of yellow(or straw).  Nice head upon pour, but quickly dissipating.  Orange citrus and pine in the nose.  Good full mouthfeel, with a generous amount of piney, dry and crisp hops.  Good malt background, with a little biteersweet chocolate and light roasted coffee notes.  But damn, the hops smack you in the face.  Maybe not the hopiest beer Ive ever had, but definitely one of the most balanced.  As it warms, the bitter hops subside just a tad, and are replaced with a smoother, sweeter balance.  Fantastic example from quite possibly the best micro in the country!

UPDATED: NOV 22, 2006 Bottle. Pours and orangey red, with a quarter inch white head. Nice hoppy and citrusy aroma.  Intense hop flavor nicely balanced by the malts. Some spiciness. Hops stay on the palate. A very crisp and refreshing IPA. Its at its best fresh. Always check the Batch number before you buy. 1 year old bottles are not as good, and there can be old ones sitting on the shelves.

Bottle. This poured a cloudy copper with a thick white head.  The aroma is hoppy and full of citrus.  The taste is a great blend of malts and hops for a nice even flavor.  The hops linger on the palate.  One of the better IPAs on the market.

12 oz. bottle.  Poured a murky copper color.  Sweet smelling aroma of hops and citrus.  This is a well balanced beer!  Obviously very hoppy, but with plenty of malts to balance it out.  Ill be drinking more of this in the future!

Cloudy copper pour offers a full-blossomed aroma of hops that is all citrus scents and pine with a little floral sweetness. The flavor is amazingly crisp and smooth given the intense hop character. This is so damn refreshing and tasty that basic descriptions fail to do it justice. The best IPA Ive had.

Bottle.  Tons of hops.  Too much for me as I prefer those IPAs on the light side of hop heaven.  None the less, this was refreshing and actually the enjoyment dwindle as the beer does as the hops were somewhat overbearing.  Still enjoyed the beer and would have another from time to time.
UPDATED: APR 13, 2006 I love hops and I love this beer.  Strong aroma of hops with straw yellow color and medium head with strong hop flavor throughout.  A VERY good IPA.

Nice deep orange color, medium frothy head. Wonderful hops nose -- hay and wildflowers - boy, I could attach the glass to my nose, running around and sniffing at it the whole day. Flowery, some lavender and hay taste with a medium long bitter aftertaste.
Strong centennial nose.  Yes!!!  Very hoppy and floral with some spice.  This is my favorite IPA.

bottle. thanks for the bottle Len. pours a cloudy golden-orange body with a large creamy/frothy white head. aroma has some creamy sweet malts and a leafy floral hop presence. smooth creamy body with big resiny citrus hops up front...yeasty and sharp towards the end with a very long piney finish. an excellent IPA.

On Tap, Bites and Brews, Pgh, PA

Light amber pour with medium white head, present intil last sip. IPAs arent usually my thing, and this was no different. It was enjoyable intil the middle, then I had problems. Aroma was floral, flavor had a spicy distinct hop kick. It was surprisingly smooth to drink for the first couple of sips. Its a good beer, just not my style.

On tap at the Clarkston Union. This light amber ale poured with a sparse white head, eliciting a very hoppy, floral aroma. The flavor, too, was quite hoppy and smooth with a carbonated mouthfeel. This is a very balance and tasty brew that goes well with most food.
i love this beer. i drink it as much as posible. when fresh this beer packs enough hops to be an IPA. nice and bitter. great for anytime of the day or year.

Cask version at Firkins, Libertyville, IL.  Hazy light amber hued having small diminishing white head with good lacing.  Lovely spicey hoppy aroma.  No discernable carbonation. Medium bodied that starts with a clean slightly sweet malt flavor with flowery hops and finishes dry with flowery hops and moderate bitterness. Nice balance of hops and malt.  A delicious tasty hoppy beer.

UPDATED: JUL 30, 2009 Pours a beautiful hazy amber color with a nice big head. aroma is very hoppy and really smells like a summer afternoon. Flavor is very well balanced there is lots of hops and some nice sweetness. also the flavor is a tad bit fruity. Flavor is very nice, however it does feel a little watery and could stand a little bit more dexture,  nevertheless this is a great IPA.
WoW!  This little devil packs a punch in the nose!  I mean that in a good way, of course.  Great floral hoppy character.  This is a great food beer.

Yes please! Bottled ambrosia...theres no ther way to describe it. Lovely, complex hop nose. Slightly opaque golden colour, thin lace of head. The palate is still tingling from the first sip. Very balanced hop profile with a lovely lingering after taste. Balance and satisfaction. The Bells brewers are gods.
Bottled.  Pours a dark gold with a small white head.  Strong citrus aromas.  Nice hops and slightly bitter on the back end.  This is one very well balanced brew.

Reddish orange. Aroma is pure dry hops, somewhat spicy. Pretty hoppy, but not overly bitter, perhaps balanced out by the good amount of malts in this one. Not sweet, but not dry either. Very well balanced and satisfying, even for someone not big into IPAs.

UPDATED: MAY 20, 2009 Wow, big pine aroma - tons of hops up front.  Its mellow and smooth, nicely bitter and well balenced.  Not watery at all.  Good full flavour throughout.  Nice malt backing, citrus and spice and spruce in the flavour.  Well done.
12 oz. bottle.  Pours a cloudy dark gold with healthy head.  Floral aroma.  Strong hoppy taste, but with floral background taste for balance.

Bottle.(6826)  Pour a cloudy light neon golden/orange, billowy medium white head, good lace and very bubbly.  Bursting with honey coated spicy hops, some light alcohol, and mild yeasty/bready notes.  Very smooth and perfect balance of caramel malt presence, with citrus, spicy hops, not to sweet and not to dry.  Not overly hoppy, but fresh and very pleasant hop presence.  Great lingering aftertaste, to what I though initially was going to be very short flavor profile.  Thin mouthfeel. High/medium drinkability.  Very nice.

UPDATED: OCT 30, 2005 Love this beer, Pours a yellowish amber color with a large slightly off white head.  Very aromatic, lots citrus grapefruit and orange with a hint of pine and perhaps a bit floral.  Medium bodied with a fruity citrus hop taste and perhaps some floral overtones with excellent balance, the malt then comes in and the finish is slightly sweet mixed with the complex hops.  Texture is creamy with a touch of hop resin.  This beer just puts a smile on my face and makes me feel good.  Excellent!  re-rated on 10/30 as the more I drink this nectur the more I like it.
Do I get extra credit if Larry Bell hands me this at GABF? Am I now cool? Do I get a hug??

Pours a yellowish copper gold color with a fading white head.  Smells like a pine forrest mixed in with flowers.  Tastes like your classic west coast IPA.  Citrusy,very hoppy with that pine needle bite to it.  Excellent.

Bottle.  Batch ID #7025.  Packaged on:  August 23, 2005.  A hazy, pale orange pour with a thin off-white head.  One of the more floral aromas Ive ever smelled.  Like fresh-cut flowers!  Lots of citrusy hops, pine needles, sap and scented soaps.  Solidly medium-bodied.  The taste is also quite floral with a good balance of citrusy hops and malts.  Almost herbal.  Finish is a bit short with no real lingering bitterness.  Unique taste.  Great beer.

The legend...at least in the midwest.  Copper amber in color with a nice yeasty haze and everlasting white head.  A floral hop aroma hits the nose in waves, followed by a light citrus hop and nice toasted malt background.  Flavor is a solid balance of caramel malt, toasted malt, floral hops & bitterness, and fruity yeast.  Nice smooth mouthfeel, not cloying but nicely sweet and lingering.  A solid IPA deserving of its reputation.
Had this on tap for the first time recently and really enjoyed it with a feta pizza. The strong hops flavor is outstanding and it complemented the cheese perfectly.
