The Aroma is spicy with notes of pepper, flowers and citrus.  It pours with a pale golden yellow color.  Kind of a spicy lemon/lime taste with some slight hop presence.  Also a subtle alcohol bite.  Pretty well balanced. Could be a little more hoppy.  Maybe I'm going by other pale ales I've tried.  An enjoyable beer.

My favorite IPA thus far.   It pours gold with a decent head and inviting citris aroma.  I didn't think the hops were quite as powerful as some other IPAs, but maybe it was just the combination of other flavours.  Either way it  hit the spot.
UPDATED: APR 28, 2006 What a beautiful tasting, smelling, and looking beer.  The aroma was very citrusy and floraly, flowing into the taste.  Ah, delicious.

tasted almost identical to a case of 12oz stone IPA's i bought recently.  a beautiful golden color with uncompromisingly dominant hops.  and a strong grassy and penny like taste that i've only noticed in the stone too.  ?

Pours a hazy yeast suspended gold with a head looking like whipped egg whites.  There is a very floral hop aroma with tiny citrus hints.  The flavor from the hops is quite different than what was expected.  The same floral hop from the aroma was present in the taste.  It was a very clean and almost perfume sweet hop flavor that was not overpoweringly bitter.  One of the most interesting hop bills I'v tasted.

I am really beginning to love these hopped up brews. Pours a beautiful orange/golden color with a creamy white head that laces the glass wonderfully. Aroma is very floral and hoppy. Flavor is matching and extremely plesant. I will be making this a regular.

Pours deep straw colored. 5 for appearance, definitely.  Excellent head and lacing.  Super hoppy, citrusy, floral, fruity aroma.  10 for aroma.  Tastes very hoppy, with nice malt base.  Finishes very smooth, with hints of hops, malt, citrus, and perfumy florals, with some Belgian white alishness and sweet candi sugar and fine chardonnay qualities.  Super complex.  Great beer.  Bells is in my top 10 brewers of all time.  My second 5.0 rating.  Perhaps I put too much emphasis on complexity, but I cannot deduct any points on this one.  Awesome!!

Bell's Two Hearted seems to be a favorite amongs mid-west hop heads. In the cask it poured a deep amber color, relativley brite, with no head. The hops burst in aroma however, the hop aroma is very citricy, pungent, like pineapple. The flavor is slightly malty but over powered by the citric hop character. The mouthfeel is somewhat resine like. There is a sweet finish for a nice overall balance. The earthy, vine like hop character is not to my liking. I much prefer a flora hop quality
Pours cloudy blonde, with an orangish haze and good large head. Bitter, hoppy, floral aroma. Bitter and floral flavors, with some slight citrus. Sort of dry finish. Not bad.

Smells hoppy and floral, though a bit metallic.  Pours cloudy golden color, with small cream colored head.  Nice lacing.  Hoppy, creamy, citrusy, bitter flavor.  Dry finish with a little sweetness.  Easy and smooth to drink.  Overall, a different, yet interesting and crisp IPA.

A very blonde IPA with a  big head. Extreme hop aroma. Very bitter but I expected more from the aroma. Only drawback was the large amount of residual sweetness. It was almost cloying as the beer warmed.

This is one damn fine IPA, the centennial hops just jump right out at you.  Quite a bit of yeast on the nose, I wonder if bottle was okay?  Fruity, citrusy, even a discernable mango note.  nice clean finish in the mouthfeel, some of the hop monsters leave you begging for saliva.
Good head, thick lacing. Strong floral aroma. Hop finish. Not overpowering. Yummy and not one-dimensioned.
UPDATED: FEB 22, 2005 Cloudy light orange color, great hoppy aroma, citrus fruity and hop taste tart grapefruit rind aftertaste, wonderful stuff
Not a hop head so this was much better than I had expected. Hoppy but not over the top, beautiful color, aroma but the flavor! Citrus, malt, crisp... a wonderful beer.

UPDATED: JUL 14, 2006 Rerate: Not sure if there is a single beer that I have enjoyed as much over the last couple of years. My desert island beer.
My lord this stuff is  tasty. My first draught beer  (just turned 21). I usually love the bitterness of IPAs, which this doesnt have, but the stuff was incredible. Had it with a $2.50 large pizza- if anybody is ever in Muncie, IN GO to the Heorot! w00t!

UPDATED: OCT 18, 2006 Poured with a great foamy head, long lasting, great lacing.  Color was very light copper, aroma of citrus and malt.  Nice rounded body that finished with a hop bite.  Very nice beer.  Rerate October 06.  Bottle from Silphium.  Medium amber colored with a slight bit of haze.  Fantastic white head that is persistant and great lacing.  Superb floral hop aroma, bits of sweet malt tickle the  olfactory.  Medium bodied.  Quite delicate in flavor, malty sweetness is gradually overtaken by a citrusy/floral hop flavor.  LIngering light bitterness that is never harsh or astringent.  This is just one fine beer.

Pours hazy orange with a thick creamy white head.

Smells of sweet fruits, some citrus and some granny smith apple.

Body is full yet the taste is light, crisp and fruity, apricots, lemon peel, and more granny smith.

This is an extremely tasty beer. Much less bitter than many IPAs, making this a very complex and diverse beer.

Highly recommended and worthy of the hype!

What a beer!  With a appetizing floral aroma and moderate to above average lacing.  This beer is so good.  In appearance very cloudy, with a very complex taste -  full of citrus, malt and others that I cannot identify.  The bitter flavor is strong but not overpowering.  This beer finishes dramatically with a nice robust fresh hop flavor.  This is absolutely, in my opinion, second to none.

A huge head exploded from the pour filling the glass. The creamy head slowly melted into a clear honey colored beer that gave off a beautiful orange citrus aroma. Malt and hops are intertwined in almost perfect harmony. Very smooth. The flavor goes from just slightly malty, to slightly bitter as it enters the finish, which slowly fades inviting another sip. One of the better IPA'a I've tried. A big thanks to Slikwily for sending this my way.

12oz bottle. I smelled the green leafy hops before the first drip hit my glass.  A very crisp, green hop aroma, lots of sweet citrus.  Nice pale gold color, clear, with a big cotton like head that never went away.  The mouthfeel was the best, very soft, good body.  The overall flavor was good, but not great (for me).  There was a bitter hop finish, but not any real hop BANG that I was expecting.  Certainly not over the top.  Very drinkable and enjoyable.

Bottle.  Poured cloudy amber with a fluffy white head that lingered well.  Aroma is dominated by floral and citrus hops with a touch of sweetness and hint of clover.  Flavor hit me with bitterness right off the bat, big grapefruit hoppiness with touches of sweetness and a little pepper.  Lingering pucker for the finish.  Medium body and creamy carbonation.  Nice ale over all, but I would have liked a bit more boldness in the malts to balance the assertive hops.

12 oz bottle; this is one of those beers that "wowed" me - seriously. I will be buying caseS of this.  Beautiful off-orange glow, fantastic hop-aroma, nice hop bite on the tongue and the aftertaste.  I would be very happy to enjoy several of these in one sitting.  Superb!

Bottle pours an orangish hue of yellow with a nice thick fluffy white head.   Carbonation is extremely lively, lacing is exceptionally sticky.   This one definately smells the part, nice hop aroma with some grapefruity and pine notes.   Initial taste shows its hop presense, yet its very mild and smooth.   Mouthfeel is very silky and full bodied for an IPA.   Quite enjoyable.   Nearing the end the hops really make their presense, finishing with a nice hoppy bitterness all over the tongue, and especially in the back.   WOW, IPAs aren't one of my favorite styles, but this one is very smooth and delicious.   Wish I had another!   Thanks goes out to ClarkVV for the trade!

Dark straw color,large white head that lasted for a nice long time leaving a nice lace behind.The aroma was faint malt but mostly pine grapefruit and Hops up the wazoo.The flavor was nicely hoppy with a mild pine presence and hops and grapefruit with a faint malt presence coming on.IMO a very nicely done IPA andone that makes me glad i bought more for later.
Hazy golden, nice creamy head. Aroma is floral, some citrus and hops. Flavor brings hops and flowers. Elder comes bacj there as well. Quite an ok ale.

UPDATED: FEB 6, 2004 Pours an amber color, quite clear except for a few large floaties.  Forms a thin beige head that does not stick around too long.  An immediate aroma of American hops wafts from my glass.  Notes of lychee, grapefruit & other citrus fruits are in the nose, it smells slightly sweet & nectar like, there is a hint of caramel malt here as well.  Ooh, quite bitter; this beer finishes with a drying intense bitterness.  Overall this beer is only slightly sweet, it has a light body & is focused entirely on the hop component.  The hops are over the top, but perhaps it is missing some hop flavor.  There is lots of bitterness, but it feels like it is missing some balancing hop nectar flavor.  Underlying the hop attack there seems to be some nuttiness, as well as some caramel notes.  This beer is all about the hop attack, not much malt here, so if you don't like hops stay away.  Luckily I do like hops so this beer is just fine.  Perhaps a bit too unbalanced for an everyday drinking beer, but every once in a while is nice.

Great color... looks like I already can smell it. (looks like the apricots and pink grapefruits it smells like just from pouring it).

There's that wonderful smell... ahhh refreshing!

GOOD taste, again, just like it looks and smells. VERY strong, very bittersweet, and very filling. So filling, I have to drop it's drinkability. SURE I loved this beer, but finishing it was rough only because I got full after half of it. Not a sesssion beer, but I will DEFINITELY return!
If you like Centennial hops or hops in general, 2Hearted is hard to beat.  Not over the top for bitterness and a very nice well rounded malt bill.  On handpump its amazing.

UPDATED: APR 11, 2004 Clear, lightly coppery color, huge, creamy white head. Aroma: juicily, piney, grapefruity, pineappley, peachy, perky, sticky, alert and ever-so-delightful, it's all you want in an IPA.First sip, warm, bright fuzzy hops, gorgeous fruit, dancing all over the palate. Fades back softly, smoothly, then it's pure liquid candy. Hops delight at every sip, tingle, tantalized. Finish is near eternal, never quitting the tongue, the palate, and the memory.The hophead's session ale, a true classic, TwoHearted is a treat from start to finish. On tap, as in this sampling, it's magic in a pint glass!

Wow. Okay, I see what the hype is all about now. This is an exceptional beer.

Pours a cloudy amber with a huge head that lasted all the way through the beer leaving a nice lace pattern.

Smells of floral hops and malt

Tastes wonderful. Grapefruit from the hops and a bit of pine. A great IPA without being over the top. Plenty of sweetness from the hops to keep it ballanced.

Mouthfeel is full and creamy. Drinkability is really good. A little bit of mineral mouthfeel would make this beer outstanding.
Light amber color. Citrusy nose with hints of malt. Sweet malty start spicy and citrus hops come through and linger.

Bottle: Citrus, lemon,orange,grapefruit.Toasted malt, toffe carmel. I think of a orange creamsicle. Pale orange yellow color. Small head that faded quickly. Poured so sediment stayed in bottle. Citrus flavors. Tad creamy, bit of bitterness on finish. Man what a great beer. No wonder why Bell's is one of the elite brewers in america.
user_location: the Containment Area, North Carolina, USA

text: 1/24/04.  Poured out of 12 oz. bottle, obtained in a trade with igneous1 on RateBeer 1/21/04.  Pours a muddy golden caramel color with an excellent rocky, off-white head and pretty good lacing.  Looks like an awesome IPA.  Aroma does not disappoint.  Very fragrant, floral hops and chewy citrus (grapefruit and lemon) and nectar notes, with a hint of pine.  Extremely compelling.  Flavor jumps right out of the glass at you-- bitter hay and grassy hop elements, still a bit of citrus, and now lots of resin, all with an overwhelming smooth malt backbone.  A faint hint of sourness with the citrus.  Very active in the mouth with carbonation, hops, and a bit of drying harshness from the resin notes.  Smooth medium body with long-lasting finish of pale malt and muted hops, a little bit dusty.  Very tasty and quaffable, and truly a great beer all-around, but not quite as fantastic as the promise of the nose.

Pours pale, yellowish and well carbonated. Head is white, frothy and leaves a residual lace.

Nose is all hops, most likely cascade and hallertau from the aroma.

Taste is sharp, somewhat thin, but with a pleasant alcohol kick.  Not as good as expected, but a nice drinking pale ale nevertheless.

Draft: Large creamy off white head, lacing, excellent aroma of grapefruit and floral hops. Tastes very hoppy, quite floral and very much like grapefruit. Does not assail the tastebuds like many IPA's. Finish is mildly bitter. Quite possible my new favorite IPA.

Lots of head (unlike my sex life).  Cloudy orange color with a distinct citrus aroma.  As far as the flavor goes, to me, this has many characteristics of IPA's and Pale Ales.  Very hoppy, hence the bitterness.  I used to say I didn't like IPA's and whatnot but I rate them all so high I obviously enjoy them immensely.

Hazy, pale orange in colour with a thick meringue head. Aromas of fragrant pine needles and Indian River grapefruit intertwined with sweet malt. Flavour is predominantly resinous, piney hops with a well structured malt backbone. The taste of hops lingers on the palate, cleansing and refreshing.
UPDATED: APR 25, 2005 My favorite and luckily my usual as well.  I love the hoppy floral aroma  and taste.  Nice and cloudy yellow/orange and a puffy white head.  Very strong and refreshing.
Hazy gold with a white head and nice lacing.  Citrus hoppy aroma.  Sharp, tart, citrus hop taste.  Very West Coast like IPA.
UPDATED: APR 21, 2005 Awesome floral nose. Beautiful lacing on top of a cloudy golden yellow brew. Smooth, hoppy flavor with almost no bite. Mellow.
This beer surprised me with its beautiful head and outstanding taste. nice clear looking and a full bold taste that makes you smile.
Starts with a good head, a little cloudy. Two Hearted's got great hop flavor and bitterness with a dry hop finish.

UPDATED: JAN 29, 2012 Perhaps its me, but Two Hearted just doesnt seem the same anymore.  Still a worthwhile drink, but it does not feel as hoppy as I think it once did.  I think its probably me.  Ive been brewing hop bombs with Citra and other really potent hops, so this mild Centennial only brew just doesnt stand up.  In the end, Ill drink it any chance that I get.
A bit subtle when compared to SN-CB, and doesn't have the initial bite that I usually feel from other IPA examples.  Definitely above average for the style, though.

Slightly hazy orange coloured body-very effervescent with a larger dense/floral off-white head. Aroma of grapefruit high a.a. hops. Mild musty aroma as well. Medium-bodied; Bittering hop flavour with citrus and floral qualities most noticed. Aftertaste clean and crisp-fairly drying, but not overpowering. An odd bitterness resides in the palate-not from hops, but from metal or something offensive. Overall, very nice to try-a well made beer with good qualities. I got this twelve ounce bottle in a six-pack from Merchant's in Dearborn, Michigan and sampled it on 24-December-2003.

Nicely hoppy aroma.  Beer pours relatively light golden color with a big off white head that is fully retained.  The foam is heavily sticking to the sides of the glass and producing prodigeous lacing.  Flavor is pleasantly bitter.  In fact this taste somewhat like the good West Coast IPAs, but not that good.  Very good, not great IPA.

Bottle

Warm, glowing, light peach with perfect clarity. Huge, puffy off-white head that fades here and there, leaving huge, cloud-like pillows of foam. Tons of sticky lace. Enormously aromatic nose with a huge blast of floral Centennial hops, with soft pink grapefruit, and hints of orange, peach, and mango. Underneath is a thin foundation of toasted malt and slightly chalky yeast. Flavor is an eruption of hop flavor and velvet hammer-like bitterness. Flowers, pink grapefruit, peaches, oranges, mangosits all there in an incredibly soft and sticky delivery. The malt and yeast manage to stay afloat enough to provide a solid base for the hop explosion happening above. Medium in body, with a soft and round mouthfeel that only gets better with the yeast pour towards the bottom. Finishes dry, firm, and bitter, with a splash of citrus and black pepper. Through my many years of better beer, this is still my favorite expression of the IPA style, and one of only a few beers that I cannot drink only one of. My opening of a bottle of this guarantees a second and third. Its worth noting that since the new brewery opened in Comstock, this beers flavor profile has been much cleaner, with much less sediment.
A lighter ale with a citrus flavor. Not as hoppy or bitter as some ales.A good beer to introduce othrs to craft brewing. Even C**rs drinkers will enjoy.

Pours a wonderful cloudy orange with a nice thick head. I recommend a tulip. Aroma is intensely bitter, smells like pure hops extract. Flavor is crisp. My palate is a battle ground between the huge bitterness and the malty goodness. What a wonderful
(Draught)  Pours a copper color with a medium-sized white head.  A light hoppy flavor with a balanced array of floral and bitter accents.

UPDATED: JUL 17, 2005 Golden-hued, loaded with millions of microparticles, well carbonated body, and relentless soft lumpy white head. Heavy lacing. Great clean, mouth-watering aroma of orange citrus, flowers, spice, and baking soda. This is a mature and superbly balanced IPA with mild sour notes. Super subtle, crisp, and smooth. A truly great beer. I could drink this forever.

UPDATED: MAY 22, 2005 Dec 15, 03: Served from a beer engine at the Map Room, and at English Ale temperature. Good thin yet persistent head. The hand pull yielded a beer with no bubbles, yet a firm mouthfeel. The IPA hops were actually subdued, nicely balanced between floral and bitter. Somehow I picked up a note of cherries, too. Color is lighter than the usual American IPA, closer to a Vienna or even a Pilsner. I had hoped to get a better impression of Bells than I did at their Eccentric Cafe taproom, and I was right.Bottled, May 22, 05. A slightly different experience from a chilled bottle, and no less fascinating. Unfiltered like the other bottled Bells, with quite a lot of bits floating around, that dont detract in the least from the enjoyment. I may have waited a bit too long to open this bottle I got in November, as the floral hops I noted on draft are a little rougher, more piney and northwestern. But just another facet of a fascinating and complex beer.

UPDATED: JUN 2, 2004 ReRate: 6/02/04: Still Killer!
I believe it was the legendary Indra that hooked me up with this bottle several months ago, Cheers Brother! 
Jesus!! This beer looks FINE; it would be a Victoria Secret model if it were a woman! A glowing orange and bronze body, with a pillow of tan frothy head and lacing The aroma is radiating from the glass, calling me in like a Siren on the ocean.. A mass of pine and cedar woods, caramel to know end, grapefruit and tangerines, brown sugar and rosemary- loads of that! 
 The flavor is far more refined and settled than the aroma;  all of the same characteristics but in moderation. The palate is like a velvet sorbet, fresh pineapple in the finish Probably the best IPA I have ever sampled, Indra~You Rock!
I Want More!!

Light gold pour with a slight haze. Huge head full of large bubbles that are popping away quickly. Not a lot of lacing however. Very nice floral hop aroma, slightly citrusy. I do have to say it has a musty pine quality to it as stated before. Nicely balanced flavors of malt and hops. Lemons are showing through a lot leaving a nice tart finish. Very crisp palate. A wonderful IPA. Thanks to EddieG for this one!

UPDATED: DEC 17, 2014 Clear light orange with a tall soapy white head.  Crisp and sharp hop aroma of peaches, scotch and musty pine.  Very crisp and light while maintaining an even hop bitterness.  Has a nice sweet wood and peach flavor.
May be my favorite IPA, has a great hop/floral aroma, very thick head that stays throughout, pretty complex but great tasting brew
(bottled) Amber colour, with hints of orange. White creamy head. Brutal aroma of citrus and strong spices. Fantastic hoppy flavour with sweet lemon in background. Long bittersweet finish.

Careful pouring this one. Whew! Springy white frothy head, golden/amber color. Aroma is full of citrus, floral, and very very hoppy. The taste is like pure hops. Some unusual fruit as well. Kind of chewy as well. Not much of a kick in the aftertaste as I thought. Overall a pretty good IPA.
Very hoppy, yet somewhat sweet. Great hoppy aroma with some fruitiness - lime maybe? Some white lacing in the glass. Almost done and still hoppy. Very good stuff.

UPDATED: APR 29, 2004 RERATE: Giving this some more points - like it a lot. Fine, solid IPA with a great balance. (Old rating notes: Fresh hop nose - kinda sweetish, hazy orange color, big fluffy had. Chewy, sweet hop taste early in the profile. Blends with the malt to give a fruitiness to the overall taste - cherries! Full mouth feel. The hops repeated on me too!)

Had a few of these with my baby last night after work.  Been wanting to try this one for a while - props to Gentile's carry out in Grandview for having a sixer this on hand.  Pours a hazy nectarine orange.  The rocky white head is fully lasting with lacing that coats my pint shaker like whale spunk.  The nose is "perfumed as fuck" according to my notes.  Oranges and limes in a spruce forest.  The flavor is bitter through and through with heavy acidity and a long finish.  The medium dry body is lively and finishes highly astringent.
aroma is of hops grassy citrusy and spicy. pours hazy golden with a white head. flavor is grassy slightly metallic, with a good hop spice to it. a very good ipa.
(hand-pull at Clark St. Ale House, Chicago) Pale gold with nice head and good lace. Pine hops predominate the aroma and flavor.

Golden cloudy, orange almost, huge head frothy tan. Alive and animated. Citriusy and sour like a grapefruit, but still hoppy in the nose. Medium body. Hoppy with a touch of citrus, almost just the acidic part of the citrus but still quite enjoyable. I was kind of pissed off with this one. When I opened it, the head exploded out of the bottle. Wasted about half of it. Bust still a lot of fun to drink.

Bottled. Aroma is delicous citrusy,floral,sweet blend. Color is deep golden with a very slight haze(pour carefully). Streams of fine bubbles with a small head and clinging lacing. Incredible flavor balance of sweet malt and citrus-floral hops. Breathtakingly refreshing dry,hoppy finish and toungue-tingling mouthfeel. Hop flavor comes back with every burp. And there are plenty. One of the few IPA's I go ga-ga over. Perhaps because it is not so one sided like others I've had. Gimme another one.

UPDATED: NOV 23, 2003 beautiful looking beer.  nice head that stays for the duration.  cloudy orange.  smells great -- floral and sweet.  very sweet and flowery tasting.. then  just the perfect amount of piney hoppiness.  overall, pretty good.   great beer for getting f!#ed up.

UPDATED: SEP 14, 2004 Light amber with a large off white head.  Very sweet aroma with floral and fruit notes - mostly grapefruit, lemon and pine. Medium body with a slight tingle of carbonation.  Flavor begins with a grapefruit and pine hop bite, and fades into a hop bitterness, caramel, and bready finish.  Very good.

UPDATED: OCT 3, 2005 Dark orange color.  Very sweet aroma, smells like candy.  Flavor starts like a full bodied ipa with hop bitternes then, nothing.  The flavor is one dimensional and not especially good at that.  Light.  Best thing about this is the unusually sweet aroma.  A dumbed-down ipa. meh.

Orange in color with a long lasting head that starts out huge, and slowly diminishes to a reasonable level.  Nice lacing is left the whole way down the glass.  Constant carbonation coming up from the bottom.  Aroma is  that of floral, hops, and grapefruit.  The mouthfeel tingles on my tounge, and all the way down.  Nice hop bite in the flavor.  It leaves a bitter finish that hangs on all parts of my mouth, but maybe just a bit too long.   For sure a great IPA, but maybe not as good as possible.
This is an exceptional IPA. It gives you a malty sweetness which I was not expecting. Most IPA's stop at the citrus character of the brew. This gave you a nice experience.

The orange gold body of this elixir is topped by a thick, lasting head with lots of lacing left behind.  The aroma is sweet and citrusy (grapefruit and lemon) from hops with piney notes and a good malty balance.  The flavor is slightly sweet yet slightly bitter and hoppy with notes of citrus and pine and a good malty sweetness for balance.  The finish is bitter and hoppy.  Medium bodied, slightly dry and relatively smooth.

This is a very nice IPA.  The hops aroma is superb.  It lingers on after the beer is swallowed.  A mixture of citrus and spicy floral aromas.  A mix that I have tasted in no other brew.  The malt is balanced against the bitterness nicely but this beer says HOPS.

First impression is pinelike crisp hops flavors. Malt is somewhere below the surface. Lots of good hops, but the balance seems a little off somewhere. Still not a bad beer for a northwoods fishing trip.

An average IPA.  Very light golden, slightly cloudy color.  Hop levels are moderate, but I don't think I like the hops they're using.  A little too sharp - even thought it's not a high-hop beer, these hops just have a twang I don't really like as much as other IPAs.

First, thanks to redlem for sending me this! Nice amber body with a small white head. Nice hoppy nose. Floral notes abound slight vanilla hint shows up as well. Very hoppy tongue. Some malt and light maple notes. Definite citrus notes - lemon or grapefruit. Bitter mouthfeel but a smooth finish; surprisingly little sharpness towards the end. Pretty good beer.

The apperance was wonderful. It is a nice burnt or orange straw color. It was clear till I swirled in the dregs from the bottle. The head is very nice. It is a nice creamy head that was huge and stucke to my glass like nothing else.

The smell was hops all the way, nothing but hops. Very floral.

The taste was very disappointing. It had hops but it was very thin and almost watery. There is very little malt in this beer and it makes it lose it's body. Could be a lot better.

Not a bad beer but not what I expected it to be.

When poured, this beer had a medium sized white frothy and creamy head with fine-medium sized bubbles that was mostly lasting. The body was cloudy and uncarbonated with a golden hue. The nose was hoppy, sweet, citrusy and fruity with a bitter and hoppy flavor. The mouthfeel was a bit tingly, smooth and dry and it was medium bodied. This beer had excellent lacing.

pale golden body, thin white head.  light floral nose with citrucy highlights.  clean, crisp and crackery.  piney and fresh.  sweet fruity bubblegum notes citrus hop charachter really comes on strong.  pretty intense, well rounded beer

UPDATED: MAR 25, 2005 sweet, citrus, toasty... - hoppy aroma. clear, straw pour. hazy copper and gold, active body. nice and tight white head that doesnt want to completely leave. fair, chaotic lacing. hoppy, citrus punch with just enough sweetness to balance. the texture is a little creamy, which is very welcome. dry, hoppy, toasty, and citrus aftertaste. the less there is in my glass, the more i want. my burps are lovely and it goes down so well. one of my favorite beers. i lick my lips, yum. UPDATE 7/13/04: mmm, its been awhile. a roomie cringed. i was in delight. she was in fright. i just about premature ejaculated. no. UPDATE 12/4/04: damn tasty--a great bitter beer... toasty orange creme beer! (downrated, though) UPDATE 1/14/05: downrated palate and overall impression. UPDATE 4/25/05: woah! holy ! damn! this beer is now local to me! thank you Famous Liquor of Decatur, IL! slightly doughy and cheesy in flavor and aroma, respectively. smooth, cremey, yet sharp palate. orangey citrus hops, biscuity sweet malts; bittersweet and delicious.
This is a great Beer. Had a floral sweet citrus nose.  Probably the best IPA aroma I've smelled.  Right up there with the other classic IPA's.  Light body, packed with hops.
Nice orange aroma.  Taste started off light and sweet, finished bitter.  Had a nice feel to it.  Really enjoyed the aroma.

Nice reddish gold with an impressive white head. Salty bread aroma. Surprising sweet and tart initial flavor, like a Flintstone vitamin (grape, Wilma). This quickly gives way to a slightly smoky, bitter hop flavor. Not a huge malt flavor, but enough to let you know it is there. Very nice.
This was by far my favorite of the Bell's I tasted. Peachy colored. Huge floral nose. Citrus undertones. Mildy sweet. Smelled so good you could wear this beer. Very nice and sooooo drinkable.

UPDATED: MAR 27, 2008 Bottle pours a nice golden color with a beautiful head that sustains and leaves lots of lace.  The aroma is flowery hops and grapefruit.  The flavor is rooted in malt but is fully challenged with hops, resulting in a fine IPA.  The palate is rich and coats the mouth.  Overall, this is very nice and will seek it out in the future.  Update 3/27/2008 - I brought home a fresh 6 pack of this as Ive not had any in over three years.  It is still freeking good.  I somehow thought it was a go to session beer, but forgot the 7% ABV.  As a result, I am pretty intoxicated, but safe at home in front of my laptop.  Cheers.

UPDATED: MAR 20, 2004 Very light copper appearance, nice creamy white head that kept a veneer the entire time.  Aroma was a pleasant burst of pink grapefruit dominated hops.  The flavor was similarly dominated by sour grapefruit, with a hint of earthiness breaking through as it warmed.  Bitter, dry finish.  Good, but a bit thin on the finish, needed just a bit of a stronger malt kick for me.  Thanks, Indra.  Note:  Sampled on tap on a business trip, almost identical profile, just not quite as creamy.

Cask at Harvest Hop Fest at Rich O's in New Albany, IN.  Nirvana!  For my taste it gets no better than this one.  I was actually a little disappointed with last year's.  It was good, but didn't kill me.  Well, IT'S BAAAAACK!  Beautiful, bright yellow with a thick, thick stiff white head.  Hop aroma exploding at you.  Creamy mouthfeel.  Flavor of grapefruit, some grassy and even some orange and spice in the hops.  Just beautiful.  How could it be better?  Give me more!

From the pour to the finish, this beer is exploding.  Great head from the bottle.  Nice hazy gold color with slight off white head that last.  Very much on the citrus aroma.  Flavor of orange that taste young.  Good balance of hops and malt.  Very solid IPA!

UPDATED: APR 1, 2004 Poured a faintly hazy orange/gold color with a moderate head and good lacing. Assertive hoppy aroma with orange, grapefruit and floral notes. Medium bodied and fresh tasting, almost raw at first, bitter and citrusy, but though the hops prevail here, there is a delicious underlying malty smoothness that makes everything alright. Lingering bittersweet finish. Whoa baby, what an ale!
Large malt backbone. Piney citricy hop flavor. The hops are pronounced but not stingingly strong. Nice IPA to drink with dinner.

This brew poured a large head of white colored long lasting buubles that left behind a carbonated light yellow orange colored body and a fair lacing.  The aroma was medium hopped and the mouthfeel was slightly tingly with a hop bite.  The flavor was hoppy but not real strong for an IPA.

UPDATED: JAN 15, 2008 Pours a light amber hue, minimal frothy head . Medium carbonation. The aroma is flowery and citric (from the Cascades no doubt). Taste is bitter and then sweet. I liked this IPA for its high level of biiterness, flowery aroma and drinkability.  Some IPAs are just too darn strong (see Dogfish Head), but this one is just right.

2003: Clear golden hue with a creamy white head and very good lace. The aroma is piney and grapefruity hops with a touch of toasted malt and twangy yeast, very floral. Citrus and bitterness is at the forefront with nice undertone of sweetness. Dry and moderate bitter finish, very smooth for something with such a hop character. Another lovely brew from Bells. Highly recommended.

Pours with a voluminous cream colored head atop a hazy orange beer with amber highlights. The head slowly recedes while it leaves a thick, sticky lace on the glass. The aroma is very sweet bubble gum with a strong lemon-pine hop presence. The sweetness is evident on the pour, and as you carry the glass to your seat. I wanted to take a drink immediately! Who needs notes anyway, right? The first drink is truly heavenly, with a great malt sweetness sparked by a terrific hop bite. What a dichotomy of tastes that somehow blend together perfectly! Very strong citrus notes are prevalent in subsequent quaffs, but the malt is never forgotten. The finish is exceptionally smooth and clean for such a flavorful beer. All that is left is a hint of fruitiness and a hint of bitterness. The mouthfeel is very rich and supple, while not becoming too heavy as the beer is finished.

Pours a light amber, with a small head and some light lacing. Medium carbonation. Aroma flowery, slightly citrusy with a slight sweet malt hint. Taste sweet, hoppy, malty, hoppy again, sweet again then slightly bitter, in that order. Not as bitter finish as I like, and also a little thin in the mouth feel for my IPA tastes (but I fear I may be jaded by the bigger, imperial IPA style), but nonetheless a very drinkable ale. The mouth feel is perhaps not thin, just different.

UPDATED: MAY 14, 2005 re-rating the cask version.  holy crap this is good.  flat and the proper temperature makes this beer even better.  the aromas are there but more subtler and more nuanced, and it has less of an overt bite, instead it softly becomes nice and bitter and perfectly balanced. wow.
original rating from bottle:  hops and citrusy malt dominate the aroma.  its light amber, semiclear, with just a little bit of head and not much lacing.  this is a full-blown IPA, with TONS of hops in the mouthfeel and finish.  you can definitely detect the dry-hopped centennials.  its all hops and its all good, with this one from bells.

UPDATED: OCT 9, 2003 Very very hoppy. Just like all of the beers that Larry makes. Helps to be from Kalamazoo to drink this beer. I will rerate when this comes out again later this month and Waldo's carries it again. 

Re-rate: Pale gold, like the Oberon that preceeds it. Large white head. Citrus sweet hops smell. A little pine. Better flavor than I remember. Bitter finish. Good.

A dark copper hue with with a white rocky head. Beautiful and inviting in my glass with yeast in suspension. The aroma is of grapefruit, yeasts and a very slight hint of caramel malt. The flavor is hoppy up front with a great maltiness to back it up. A bitterness prevails in the aftertaste and notes of pine.
Excellent hop aroma and an over all great flavor, save for the obvious infections.  DMS and occasional phenolics are obvious in this years batch.  Overexpansion has come at a cost!

Wow!, teh aroma is a blend of apricot,grapefruit and maybe orange, very nice. Pours amber/orange with a decent head. My first taste made me say "whoa!" I'm glad I bought this beer. It's a bit sour and has a thick citrus taste. Maybe not a session beer, but I think I'm going to knock down the other 5 in the fridge tonight anyway. Packs a bit of a punch with a nice aftertaste.
Very enticing thick, froth, accompanied by a very crisp, flowery aroma.  Creamy, full, smooth - feels really nice in your mouth.  A bit tart...delicious.

Aroma is of slightly herbal European hops with a hint of leather. It is an unfiltered auburn color with white head and smooth lacing. An extremely light body for so much hops and alcohol. Dry, bitter, and almost watered down on the palate which makes this very refreshing and would be exceptional with some spicy food. Overall this is a good IPA with lots of hops and a great unique mouth feel for some hidden complexities. Thanks Indra!

This was an extyremely tasty first beer of the evening.  Mild aroma, with largely hoppy scents emenating from the bottle upon opening.  Beautiful frothy head, that looks extremely cloudy and unfiltered.  The taste overwhelms your tongue with flavor, medium bodied and extremely hoppy, but not as much as I expected.  Very well balanced, and clean and easy to drink.  I could easily drink several of these just because of the lightness in the mouth.
Clean and crisp in the finish with a slight bit of bitter sweetness.

Sean's Uncle Jim dotes on this stuff.  His hopheadedness accompanies his love of very hot sauces and I think that might be the way to enjoy this brew, strength to strength.  By itself it bitters my tongue to parchment.  A kinder gentler torture due to the mouthfeel ...

Very nice. Hopped only with centennial and you can tell. Does not have the super "cascady" aroma of other IPAs but still the armoa is very nice. Some citrus notes.  Very hoppy ~60IBUs. Body nice and chewy but not too much so.

UPDATED: FEB 29, 2008 Rerate This stuff is now available regularly in these here parts and I actually broke down and bought a whole six. Have enjoyed each one more than the last - surely deserves to be rated as my highest IPA - up a notch or two. Aroma and flavor more intense yet so overwhelmingly well balanced. Original 4.1 Bottle overflowed upon opening - which led to a thick sticky white head. Orangeish hazy appearance. Very pleasing fresh citrusy aroma. Very thick mouthfeel - can almost chew it. Bittersweet citrusy flavor. Strong finish and also a lot of sediment remaining on the bottom of the glass. Overall, an excellent IPA from Bells - have not had a bad one yet from them.

Golden, slightly amber color.  Lacing on the (plastic) glass.  One hop variety in the beer (centennial), and you can clearly tell in the aroma.  Some citrus in the aroma and in the flavor.  Sharp citrus, like orange peel.  Very, very nice hoppiness.  Yummy!

purchased this from Int'l Beverage in Grand Rapids on my way back from K-Zoo, the fish on the case definitely reminded me that this brew was made in good old west michigan, i didnt really think of this as an IPA until i looked it up on here, i thought it was a rather robust american strong ale, reminded me of Arrogant Bastard almost, intense hops, medium thick body, with a refreshing citrus circus going on in there, topped off with some malty cream flavor, the mix was done properly, and i dont think Hop Devil could carry this mans jock strap around

There's a lot going on here: Good, persistent head; Medium to full body and mouthfeel; Alcohol presence is noticable; Good hops pacing from bitter at the front to complex, almost licorice-like at the end (dry hops and maybe hop oil). Regardless of the serving method, tap, bottle, hand-pump, it's always consistently good. Maybe their best beer.

Had from bottle on July 6th, 2003 - Day 6 of Blake's Beer MonthI'm a sucker for IPAs and this one is no different - it pours with a hazy gold color and a yellow-tinted head.  The head diminishes quickly, but leaves lacing behind.  Aroma is hoppy as is the taste.  Flavor is of citrus - most notably grapefruit - a bit tart, but not so much so.  An interesting brew and a great job by the folks @ Kalamazoo.

Color was a solid goldish yellow, small bubbly head that faded fast but left nice tight lace in patches around the glass. Aroma is very grapefruit/orangey/lemony peel-like with lots of fresh floral hops and a bit of spice. Straight up taste is very fresh hops, citrusy with some spice notes and grain, nothing overbearing, very mellow, its perfectly balanced and is very crisp and clean with a great, light dry finish. Hard and very bold, medium body feel, somewhat creamy with lots of fruity sweetness and a nice, light dry finish. This is some fantastic stuff.
Good IPA. Just the right amount of hop flavor. Wasn't too over the top.
Another fine brew from Kalamazoo Brewing Company.  Good hops, with a lemon-citrus flavor.
UPDATED: JUN 26, 2003 Bottled. Cloudy orange with creamy head. Citrusy nose. Sweet and medium bodied with a relatively hoppy grapefruity finish. The mouthfeel is light and sparkling.

UPDATED: MAR 22, 2005 2002 bottle. Dark Brownish Red ale.  This was interesting. For some reason I didnt care for the mixture of hops in this one.  Needs something more. If ever there was a case of a too-hoppy-IPA this might be it.  Though, I dont mind Sierra Nevadas PA or Ipswichs Ipa. I suppose I shall have to buy this beer and review it.Rerate.  Not much changed from first impression.  The heavy hops flavor, with the additional dry hopping creates a tough act to balance, and the pale crystal malt does not get the job done.  Sure, it tastes wonderfully of hops and is fresh and clean, but there just is not enough good malt flavoring.  Points for a good yeasty flavor though, dont get that often in IPAs.  Aroma is very dry, some yeast, some earthy hops. 2003 FRESH bottle. Ok, well it looks like I got my first case of bells gone bad in the previous ratings.  Guess those 2002 bottles had sat out too long.  These new bottles were much better. Gone is the astringent, stale taste.  Much better balance than I remember, but there is a weird alcohol flavor in the body that is quite prevalent on the finish.  Not pleasant at all. I just dont seem to get along with this beer.

Dark golden body - lasting, big bubbled head.  Very dry like champagne.  Smells somewhat sweet and hoppy.  The flavor is robustly hoppy, but not too bitter at all.  A very smooth finish, with some vanilla notes.  Alcohol is definetly present.

UPDATED: JUL 15, 2003 One of the best IPA's I've had in recent memory. Cloudy copper ale with nice fluffy head, which is the sign of great quality ales. Aroma is superb, piney and citrusy. Has it's own uniqueness to it and different from other great IPA's. I smell a little cedar as another reviewer points out. Nice lacing. Very crisp and carbonation is solid. I only wish I could buy these locally. Would be a regular for me.
user_location: Cape Coral Waterfront Wonderland, Florida, USA

text: UPDATED: DEC 31, 2014 (Had several more times over the years - its a dang good IPA, but there are plenty of better ones out there) Cloudy golden color, high carbonation, small but creamy head - citrus and hops in the aroma in abundance - flavor is very woody, with heaping helpings of various hop varieties that coat the tongue much in the way malts would do in a sweeter beer (its an odd sensation, but enjoyable) - great hop finish, not overly bitter, with some hints of cedar - this is an excellent IPA

UPDATED: MAY 28, 2004 Strong cedary, piney, grapefruity, citrusy nose, no doubt due to the hops. Smooth sweetish maltyness. Sharp bitterness at the end, with some saltyness and some alcohol noticed, lingering bitterness. Grapefruity and a bit woody?. I don't know, to me this wasn't very exciting, a bit one dimensional, even though it had quite a lot of flavour, i found it pretty easy to pick apart. Still, quite alright. (Re- rate, better than i remembered it, so i marked it up a bit- thanks to mwsf)
Coppery with great big head.  Well hopped,  touch of malt, and a crisp,  clean finish.

UPDATED: MAR 16, 2006 Nice dark golden color. Fluffy white head. Great earthy and citric hop aroma and appropriate flavor. Good balance from the candy sweet malt. More bitterness than malt flavor as expected. Overall a great beer.
UPDATED: MAY 30, 2003 Very hoppy aroma. Cloudy golden in color. bitter feel on palate. Thick creamy head that lasts.Not as much hoppiness like some ipa's. A excellent belle's product.

UPDATED: JUL 8, 2005 4/02/04: Re-Rate. Almost a year later and on tap instead of teh bottle, my feelings regarding the Two Hearted are virtually unchanged. Independently, I gave the draught version a 17 overall and the Flavor an 8 instead of a 9. Very piney and hops up nicely as it warms. A nice enjoyable beer! 4/27/03: Very hoppy aroma, but on the dry side. Large, foamy, off-white head; somewhat rocky. Amber, hazy color. Decent lace. Hoppy, sweet and alcholic flavor; full-bodied and very tasty. Well balanced with malt notes evident.

Typical IPA aroma, floral, citrus, and generally sweet.  Clowdy golden darker color, modest white head.  Palate is top notch. Not overly hopped, not too forced. Slight feel of apple and orange in the flavor.  Once again, bells produces a great beer.
Nice clean coppery brew. Hoppy aroma and nice hop bitterness throughout. Clingy lace.

UPDATED: SEP 7, 2004 Awesome IPA, copper in color, just a bit of a bubbly head lining the perimeter of the glass, very floral & hoppy aroma, dry & bitter flavors filled with lots of hops, dry & bitter aftertaste as well, very excellent pale ale
Awsome... Very unique floral orange aroma accented by a bit of malt (cotton candy, concord grapes). Semi sweet with a pine/resin/orange rind finish. Absolutely great.

UPDATED: MAR 8, 2014 Glowing golden orange. Thinnish head. Some lace. Fruity, hoppy aroma. Intensely bitter. Very dry. Medium to full bodied. Nearly perfect but I find myself wishing for more citrus or piny flavors along with the hoppy bitterness. Over time, this has become one of my go-to beers and I drink it on tap and on cask all the time. Try it, youll like it.
Huge citrus/pine nose, pours a hazy orange color.  Thick mouthfeel, starts and ends very bitter.  A real standout IPA that all hopheads should try.

UPDATED: APR 14, 2003 Monster head.  A dark yellow color, opaque.  Very fruity and hoppy aroma.  Taste is fruity, maybe more citrus as well.  Weird flavor.  This is unlike any IPA I've had before.  Just leaves me a queezy after affect.

UPDATED: APR 17, 2003 As you pour this beer, you are greeted with a molasses/honey aroma, intertwined with a noticeable smell of alcohol.  Enormous head that lasts until the end.  Initial blast is a bitter/winey flavor with fruity notes.  The hops, though prevalent, are rather subdued.  As the beer warms the flavor really devolops and the hops come alive.  Very smooth finish.  A nice overall ale, and a unique offering.  Sort of an American strong ale.

This beer is a real pleasant surprise. Don't be fooled by the plain label and absence of fancy graphics. The beer pours with a nice finely laced head. the aroma is citrus, very reminiscent of some of the better Belgian's. It's strongly hopped an has a long fruitey palate. I have had it both in the bottle and on tap. The draught beer has more fruity nose and is in my opinion better than the bottled presentation. A keeper.
Big creamy cloud like head, very cloudy light brown color.  A sharp but pleasent hops nose, with ton of flavors.  Thanks jsquire for sending me this.
Dark Golden beer with a fine head.  Nice hoppy dry aroma.  Good hops with a dry finish.  Full mouthfeel.  Nice texture.

This is a very good IPA.  Poured a dark golden light orange color with an off white head.  The taste is very balanced but I found it to be a little thinner in body than most IPA's.  Still, a very good beer.

3/28/03: on cask at the smokehouse.  particularly cloudy (very evident that it was the end of the cask.)  peach in color and creamy looking.  heavily laced down to the last drop.  aroma of douglas fir trees, dirty hops, and yeast (i swear that i also smell hints of bubble gum??)  creamy tasting with lots of hops, and some orange and lemon. a real ale, served at room temp.

This is a GREAT beer for an IPA lover (or almost anyone for that matter).  The only thing I slightly didn't like was the lighter color.  This beer pours great, tastes great, leaves a nice head that coats the glass, and keeps you coming back for more.
Complex flavors. Very tasty. This one has made it into my top 5 all time favs. Still have not identified all the different flavors in this beer. Also need to try it as my first beer...

Hazey orange/gold with a big off white fluffy head.Great laceing.Large citrusy,spicey hop nose. Med/fuul body.Over carbonated.Piney,citrusy flavors all over.Also get some vegetal notes.Dry,overly bitter finish.

Intense hops bitterness aroma...similar to many barley wines I've had...Avery Hog Heaven comes to mind. The color is a nice hazy yellow-orange with a large frothy white head. The flavor is more sweet...lots of malty goodness with an intense hops kick...grapefruit finish.

Slightly hazy orange amber beer with a big frothy white head that left impressive lacing.  The aroma is of citrusy hops and underlying malt.  Flavor is sweet malt on the tongue at first, followed by a potent citrusy hop flavor, and decent hop bitterness in the finish.  A medium mouthfeel with medium carbonation makes for a refreshing yet substantial beer.  Overall a superbly balanced and full-flavored IPA.

This one pours a slightly cloudy amber color with a medium sized, lingering white head. Strong aroma of hops with touches of orange, grapefruit, and lemon that reminds me of of the way lemon poundcake with icing smells. Medium body with medium carbonation, the flavor is just what the aroma predicts, a big, hoppy, fruity tasting IPA. This beer tastes like lemon pound cake to me. Smooth and undeniably wonderful, this is one of the better balanced and better flavored IPA's I have tried. Excellent!

Wow! What a surpise! A great complex beer. Even my wife liked it and that says a lot. Sweet fruity hop aroma. Dark golden, white head, very good lace. Light sweet, very complex and fruity, very hoppy. Little thin, could use some body. Short finish with some bitterness and a little dry. Thank you aceofhearts for sending this to me!

This beer pours a rusty color and has a very thick and solid head.  The aroma is strong with citrus and malt.  The taste is one of a kind, but not to my liking.  It is filled with different flavors to be examined, but the taste was too bitter for my liking.

Not too sure about this "coppery color", more of a cloudy honey.  Medium creamy head that left some laceing and a thick resinouse nose.Thick creamy mouthfeel filled with lots of resinous hops.  Maltyness pairs with the hops to make a beutiful bittersweet charactor.   Not too unsimilar to Yulesmith

I really enjoyed this brew. Nice sweet flowery smell sour sweet smell. There is nothing really in appearance that strikes me. The flavour is really striking very nice. Sweet, flowery. Creamy head hopy.. Very nice. This is really good. Very hopy.

This is as *nice* of an IPA as I've tasted anywhere--preferred over the Victory Hop Devil.  It is just so nicely balanced, so nicely creamy (long-lasting creamy white head) yet pointed in its carbonation, so nicely, gently bitter.  A nice counterpoint to a meal of Italian sausage and spaghetti.  All those compliments, and I really don't even care for IPAs that much....

UPDATED: JAN 16, 2014 Just to begin, the aroma of this beer is fantastic and the deep, cloudy golden copper color is very nice too. The flavor is nice and hoppy, but still fairly smooth and good on the palate. Overall, this is truly an exceptional beer, and one that I will definitely purchase again!

UPDATED: JUN 1, 2004 Time to dump an old review.  After 600+ ratings, this is still my favorite IPA (not counting I2PAs).  Pours with a hazy golden body topped by a medium off-white head.  The hops aroma and flavor really shines- some notes of pine and citrus (grapefruit, lemon) are present but the intense floral characteristics combine with sweet, tangy malt to create an awesome, creamy palate.  Now that this is available year-round, it makes a nice "stock" beer to keep in the fridge as it is highly drinkable.
Great beer.  I have had both bottle and tap and it holds up well in the bottle.  Hugely hoppy but it stays in balance.  Clean and almost lemony.  Great brewer.
Gorgeous beer to pour, great hop flavor.  And those are fish on the bottle--it took me a while to figure that one out.

Clear golden color with a thick, white merangue head that lasts and leaves a healthy lacing on the glass. Super hop aroma - sweet, piney, resin and grapefruit. The flavor is a blast of hops. Hoppy, sweeet, and a hint of Pez candy! The hops in this beer add a lot of bitterness. Subdued malt flavor. Lasting hop aftertaste. Heavy carbonation and a moderate, resiny mouthfeel. Quite enjoyable.

UPDATED: OCT 3, 2003 Re-rate.  I dont know what happened the first time I tasted this but it is very different, perhaps the keg was bad.  This is wonderful on all senses.  A smooth orange color with a medium creamy white head.  Aroma is a mix of fruits, it is hard to pick out but peaches come to the front.  Silky smooth feel.  Taste is fruity, not very bitter, English like.  I need to get more.

Too bitter yet light; hard to identify flavors.    Concealed the alcohol well though.  smell was nice, but not all that intense.  Not much head when I had it on tap but lacing lasted throughout, easy enough to drink. Great 3rd or so beer, because by then you can tolerate the bitterness and can take advantage of the alcohol.
Some hoppy goodness, mixed with some bitterness and some citrus notes.  One of my favorites.

UPDATED: MAR 10, 2003 I've had this beer in bottle and draught and definitely prefer the draught as it's quite a bit smoother.  Makes a wonderful sweet first impression with a nice hoppy zing at the end.  A nice break from the overly-hopped IPAs that one usually gets.  The subtlety of Two Hearted on tap almost reminded me of a bitter, except that it had a bit more of a head.  Does that make any sense?

I think that if you served a two-hearted ale to a guy with a steak and some mashed potatoes, he'd probably propose to you between mouthfuls.

UPDATED: MAY 13, 2004 Do not underestimate this beer from its appearance.  It looks like an American macro but tastes like a top-notch IPA.  Lots of small bubbles give this fully hopped beer a champagne-like texture.

Re-rate: Had this in a fresh bottle and boy did it make a difference! Explosions of fresh fruit and flower hops.  So nuanced, soft and sweet.  This is the least abrasive, most delicate IPA I've had.  Maybe that's why it doesn't stay so long in the bottle (based on my other samples).  Find it fresh on tap or check the date on the box and you will not be sorry.

UPDATED: JAN 18, 2003 extremely cloudy yet beautiful..like a sunset..the aroma was juicy fruity bits of mango..a little mustiness..wow that mango is crazy..with a hint of a champagne aroma at the very end after sniffing real hard for a while..and a shot of pineapple..pineapple mimosas anyone?..the first thing i notice is complete balance..the next is the subtly sweet mango fruity taste..some citrus..maybe tangerine..yet not too sweet..not too bitter either..but a delight..the next progression of flavors is as follows..a hint of yellow watermelon, soil, dirt, and earth, green veggie, spinach, celery, back to sweeter fruits, pineapple, maybe some more unripe and unsweet mango..kiwi..this is a treat..
Excellent IPA. Great drink + Great company = Great day.

UPDATED: AUG 20, 2009 The fruity smell was almost overwhelming as soon as I cracked the bottle.  Visualy it was a beautiful amber/orange color.  It tastes quite fruity, like biting into a beer version of a fresh peach, and its more hopped up than that guy standing outside the liquor store asking you for your change.  The palate is pretty thick, especially for an IPA.  Without a doubt this is my favourite IPA that I have sampled.
I think this is probably one of my favorite pale ales ive had.  It is not overpowering, but has great hop taste.
deep straw apperance, medium  carbonation. Thick for an IPA, fairly well balanced, creamy nice feel in your mouth,dry finish. I would recommended it for IPA lovers.
A superior IPA.  Perfect in nearly every way, with a strong hop finish that is pleasantly citrusy.  It is a shame that you cant get this beer year round, but with the new factory that should change.
On tap in K-zoo:  This beer was great, a nice hoppy aroma.  Hazy hoppy flavor.  Pretty much this IPA is everything an IPA should be.

A cloudy orange brew with a nice head and good bubbles.  A fruity nose to complement the wonderful hop aroma.  I taste citrus, maybe orange and even some spices that I really like.  Bitter aftertaste with lingering hop flavors.  A different IPA than many others I have had.  Nonetheless, it is a refreshing beer that I hope to consume a few more times this summer.
RE-RATE: Just had fresh off tap from the Eccentric Cafe in K-Zoo.  Wonderful hop aroma, one of the best.  This is by far my favorite IPA: the hops are well placed and totally enjoyable.  Right in accordance with style guidlines.

Word to the hops, dawg.  This beer is great, as are all the other Bells products Ive tried.  Wicked hop kick with supreme balance and a bit of earthiness to fulfill the entire palate.  Support Bells, so they brew forever.  Losing this brewery will be a serious blow to the world of craft brewing.

(On tap)
Golden, straw colored body with a thin white head.
Very floral aroma.
Spicy hop flavors with a hint of the malt.
Smooth on the tongue with a lingering hop aftertaste.
Good example of an IPA that actually sticks to the style guidelines without going over the top.

On tap at the Old Chicago in Rockford, IL (relatively worthless chain pubs; 110 beers are almost all nationally available and half of them are macros).  Decent, very bitter IPA; the hops are evident from the first spicy whiff, through the strongly bitter body and the long harsh finish.  Body is hearty and strong, but overall malt is not present enough for me; unbalanced.  Not one of Bells best IMHO.

My first IPA, and frankly, I was expecting more.  Dont get me wrong, this was a very drinkable beer.  I just expected more hop bitterness.  Light copper-colored with a rich, thick head.  Hazy in appearance with a few floaties in there.  The aroma...oh the aroma.  Smells like fresh hops in the christmas tree.  Very full mouthfeel with that hop aroma taste, but little bitterness.  Finishes smooth, with some of that hoppy taste staying behind.I do very much like this beer, but I expected more bitterness, like their amber ale, only lighter.

The aroma is of hop blossoms, FTD flowers, fir trees and freshly ground black pepper.
Hazy, deep golden hue with a large, rocky white head. Mostly, but not fully diminishing with great lacing.
The flavor is that of bitter juniper berries and pine/fir with just a suggestion of the heavy malt and high gravity alcohol.
Full-bodied with soft carbonation and a creamy mouthfeel.
Long, citrisy, bone-dry finish with a woodsy, gin-laden whisper at the far end.
Very nice IPA.
A very very tasty IPA. Incredible tangy and long-lasting flavor. The beauty of this IPA lies in its uniqueness. One to experience again and again.

A little jagged around the edges, but a fine brew none the less. This beer tastes more like apricots than some apricot beers Ive tried. The alcohol is not well disguised; it rears up and gallups right out your nose in a hurry. Unfortunately, the splendid apricot nose becomes intwined with a piney, resinous middle hops taste, and the two just dont jibe. Think of apricot jam smeared over a pine cone, and doused with Grand Marnier.
didnt go well with the stout i just had.  Nice light hoppy flavor.  Fruity smelling... not bad at all

(on tap) About as subtle as a Little Richard performance.  Copperish color with a gorgeous head that settles down after a few minutes, but never completely disappears.  Supercharged initial hop taste that gives way quickly to a unique tartness.  Seems almost sour at first but after a few sips, the taste settles in nicely.

Marvelous stuff.
copper, golden color with a slight haze.  nice, big aroma.

Deep golden with a lot of extra proteins/yeasts floating about. Somewhat rocky, light cream colored head.  Aroma of fresh handed rolled hops - citric, pine oils overflow.  Sharp grapefruit citrus strikes the palate as the liquid glides and yet stings.  Finishes with the necessary malt sweetness to help you wonder what all the previous excitement, the synapses were firing on about, was all about.
One if my first IPAs. Great light copper color, not super hoppy, all in all a great brew!

UPDATED: JUL 14, 2005 I am IPA lover and this one is my beer of choice.  Each and every time I pick one up Im amazed all over again.  If you are a fan of contennial hops(grapefruit, citrus,etc) this is the IPA for you.  A pleasant blend of hops and malt, low enough in alcohol that you dont have to be real careful with the number you consume, its one that I can enjoy a sixer of and not take leave of my senses.

Probably the most hop flavor I have ever tasted in an IPA.  Very crisp and a little tart, the hop flavor definitely dominates.  This beers starts out with a bit of sweetness and finishes bitter and stays bitter for a long while.  Definitely worth getting again but only when I have an extra craving for heavily hopped beers.

UPDATED: JUL 5, 2003 What an amazing beer.  There is a temptation to dismiss this as an over-the-top, totally imbalanced, excessive hop monster.  Indeed, for hop character, I think this is more intense than Victory, Alpha King, and even perhaps Stone IPA.  But I find it impossible to denigrate this beer.  Upon opening the bottle, the raw hop fragrance stunned me.  The hop flavor provided a wonderful citric vibrance throughout the bottle, twisting and turning and showing new flavor features.  Quite an experience.  There is some nuance in this hop monster and it is simply wonderful.  Thank you for this one, Psych Prof.

Delicious on tap and from the bottle.  Light bronze, lacy head.  Smooth, distinct bitterness and excellent hop aroma and flavor.  A lot of citrus - grapefruit and lime.  Mild sweetness balances this off nicely.
Nice crystal clear brew.  Head clings to the side of the glass.  Nice hop aroma, with a great bitterness throughout.

UPDATED: AUG 16, 2005 Beautiful hazy orange/amber color.  Huge creamy head that outlasts the beer. Fascinating resinous, citrusy aroma.  Flavors are of grapefruit sweetened with sugar.  The sweet, medium to full malt body balances the huge hop presence perfectly.  Fantastic.

This beer is unfortunately very inconsistent in the bottle.  Ill just say that this rating is for the kegged version or the best of the bottled samples Ive had.

UPDATED: NOV 9, 2003 2003 bottle-im boosting the ratings on this brew.  The aroma is not as strong as last years, but its more orangy than last years.  i love the cloudy appearance for this brew, and i bumped that up too.  World class IPA-thanks to Bunkypop for hooking me up with this one!
ReRate-11/23/02 on tap at Old Chicago-Rockford, IL-The bottles that i had of this months ago must have been skunked.  On Tap, this is world class.  This is one of the more malty ipa's out there, but is very well balanced, moreso than SN celebration.  I tested the two head to head.  I still like the SN celebration more, but this runs right on its heals.
Old Rating-
Not as good as i was wanting it to be.  the start is great IPA hop, but the middle is kind of wierd, hard to describe.  This kind of got to me.  High alcohol presence, being at 7%.  The finish was a little light for most IPA's-i think i will stick to the New Glarus hop hearty and the Goose Island IPA.

UPDATED: FEB 10, 2013 Hop phantoms had invaded my tongue and declared it a ghost palate...I was desperately À la Recherche du Houblon Perdu...Remembrances of a real IPA were slowly drifting away...And my tastebuds, naively still open, were about to lose faith...Until (perchance!) a horde of Michigan soldier bees commenced the emergency pollenization of my forlorn tongue...Immediatly, hop vines started to thrive, citrus fruit started to multiply and firs grew bigger and firmer...A smell of lush jungle vegetation and toasted cereals started to emanate from my still reeling palate...Two Hearted Ale is always a quenching reawakening...
Very impressive. Nice sort of golden color with a substantial head. Flavor is a citrus hint with a nice bitter finish. Definitely will be looking to find more of this.
UPDATED: MAY 31, 2014    Very hoppy, with a smooth floral malt character.  Malt is slightly fruity, and medium bodied. Crisp hop finish, with delcious citrus and floral notes lingering.

Wow! ....
Floral hoppy, grapefruit nose. Big long lasting head. TONS of lacing. Orangish in color, belgiany/malty, then light sweet, then all hop finish. DEFINATELY a hopheads dream. Excellent IPA!
Great head, cloudy yellow color....aroma was typical of an IPA but I was somewhat disappointed by the flavor....seemed a bit too malty for an IPA, IMHO....had an annoying acidic finish.
The cloudiness seems appropriate.  Mild, sweet, and fresh.  Wonderfully peppy and sassy.  Round with a nice aftertaste.  I could drink this one all night.
An awesome IPA & a staple in my beer buying.  I never tire of this beer.  Its bitterness is perfect. Unfiltered just how I like it.
UPDATED: MAR 24, 2003 Beautiful head (calm down boys);gorgeous color; strange smell.  Sweet citrus and solid malt combo  explodes flavor on your tongue. Thank you sir I'll have another.
user_location: Middle of no where, Ohio, USA

text: Cloudy yellow/orange body with eggshell white head. Aroma is solid hoppy grapefruit.  Flavor is grapefruit, but balanced with solid malt backbone.  Chewy.
a treat for the tongue.  sweet hops with a distinct fresh smelling sweetness to it.  citrus hint.  world class in my book.
This bottle exploded in a foam furry on opening.  Aroma is very smokey - reminds me of drinking a smokey IPA with a lot of citrus.  I couldnt see drinking a lot of this ale, not even 1/2 a bottle.
medium golden color, with a thin white head. aroma and flavor are big on the grapefruit. aroma is also a bit musty and earthy. nice bitter finish to this one.

cask conditioned version on tap... I must say the aroma is all floral, and not in a subtle way either, its like a goddamned conservatory... due to the ridiculous amount of hops... which is to be expected in an IPA... slight fruit and florally flavor that is added by the aroma alone, perhaps a gentle spice... of course, this is hoppy as all hell, almost too hoppy really... and is unrelenting from start to wonderfully dry finish. Not really the biggest fan of IPAs anymore; too forward in its intentions for my taste... but as IPAs go, this one blows them all out of the water.
An unfiltered monster IPA with a great flavor. Thanks, Dank

Nice cloudy amber color with a medium-sized white head.  Solid hop nose with grapefruit and resin shinig through.  The relentless hop blast in this beer just gets more intense from start to finish.  Grapefruit and citris rinds abound from the initial taste all the way through the finish with malt clearly taking a back seat, which I didnt mind at all.  A supurb example of American hop aromas and flavors.  Average body.  Very pleasant to a hophead.

UPDATED: JUL 18, 2004 Dark golden color with a rich lacey white head.  Huge hoppy bouquet with floral attributes.  Very well balanced malty body and tart bitterness.  The finish is dry and crisp, and the higher abv is undectable.  I have yet to have a bad Bells beer.

Quite complex for a strong IPA.  I couldnt quite put my finger on it, but this is somehow quite bitter and hoppy while not having the stereotype west coast hopped to hell taste.  Intensely floral aroma.  Orange, lemon, grapefruit in the flavor, and hints of pretty much all other citrus fruits.  Maybe a little bit too lasting of an aftertaste, but this is another winner from K-B.

Now heres an interesting beer - it has quite a bite to it!  This is going to sound odd but ya know how sometimes in fancy restaurants they put so-called edible flowers on your plate as a garnish.  Well, I dont think you are supposed to eat them, but one time I decided to try one just to see what it tasted like - I believe I was eating a marigold that I ended up having to spit out, but there is a bit of a stinging bite to the marigold that I find in this beer. However, the makers of this beer must have found a good balance because I didnt feel like I had to spit it out.  In fact it is quite good!

UPDATED: FEB 8, 2008 On tap at Rich Os in New Albany, Indiana. Good. Could have been a little colder IMO when I had this. Hoppy. No 3 Floyds Dreadnaught but not bad.

Rerate: draft from the mini keg- always one of my favorite beers, this beer from the mini keg poured orange-ish yellow with a thick off white head. Citrusy and grassy hop aroma. Very full. Spiderweb lacing on my glass. Flavor is full of citrus and pine flavors, decent body, not rich but smooth. Thanks to KP for sending me the kegs.
Gold color. Large head. Hoppy aroma. Malty and hoppy. Big and bold flavor. High alcohol, but smooth taste. Mouthfeel is full. Finish is dry. Aftertaste is slightly bitter. Nice beer.
Smells like DFH 90 Minute, big blunt and textured hoppiness evidence of intense dry hopping, a bit like barley wine, toasty and alcoholic, slightly soft. Appearance marred by my oily glass.

UPDATED: JAN 22, 2003 Update 1/22/03.Excuse me, I must have been on crack that day. The balance is superb as this beer is.  Dark golden pour with a fluffy white head.Big hop nose,floral.Balance is a little off but still a fine brew.

Extremely big hop nose on this IPA. The beer poured flawlessly and produced one fine looking glass of beer. The mouth feel is very dry and bitter. The hops are straight forward, kissing you on the face with PNW goodness. The beer gets drier with each sip; I think it could be a little bit more malty in order to make it a better-balanced IPA. However, this is still an excellent IPA. Thanks hopsrus.
Sweet, inviting floral nose, springlike.   Nice hop presence in the sweet almost suryp-like body.   Has a ginger(?) spicy bitter finish.

The hops flavor of this IPA has an explosive crescendo that turns into a gentle landing with little to no unpleasant aftertaste. I think a better name might be Two Fisted Ale. Other than the gentle aftertaste this beer packs a straight punch of flavor. However, that name wouldnt attract as many customers. I have to give the aroma much lower than everyone else. I tried nearly two six packs before writing this (not all at once!) I just dont get the aroma everyone talks about. This is a first rate IPA and Ill keep testing it until I do. One last point, Kalamazoo should consider labeling this as an IPA. I only bought it because of the name and the wonderful label.

UPDATED: SEP 24, 2003 2003 RE-Rate:  Another fresh bottle this year - hops are strong and sweet in the aroma, great cloudy orange body, palate is nice and thick - there's a good amount of malt sweetness balancing it out. RE-rate:  O.K., 3rd times a charm.  This time it's got a real nice sharp/sweet hop - an above average IBU.  Still get a little metal in the flavor too, though.  I begrudgingly up my rating.  

original: I love IPA, didn't like this very much, didn't even think it was IPA. mine wasn't that hoppy, had metal aftertaste. maybe it had gone bad? but it didnt taste as bad as bell's amber ale... I prefer this brewer's dark stuff.
Strong hop smell and taste. This is Excellent! The hop flavor lasts and lasts.

Hops, hops, hops and taste.  This is Real Ale.  I have bumped up my rating.  The flavor of this beer can sprain a taste bud.  That is the sign of a good brew. Re-rate: 4/2/02  Had this on tap finally.  Pours much clearer off the tap than the bottle.  Floral smell and a wonderful hop taste that stays with you long after you swallow.  One of my favorite beers without question.Re-rate again 4/22/02: I have to bump this all the way up. Its tough for me to do this as a perfect mark is tough to give out, but for me, it is perfect. This is my favorite beer!  It just gets better and better.  The addictive bitterness of the hops, the wonderful mouthfeel after the finish...Excellent.Re-Rate 10/3/02Still my favorite beer.  This years version is as fresh as ever with an incredible grapefruit smell and initial taste.  These hops are addicting...

This one should be available year-round!  Simply one of the best IPAs around.  Hops galore and finishes with a nice hoppy bite. Did I mention that this is one seriously hopped IPA!  Great Stuff! 
Re-Rate:  Just got some more and noticed a more piney flavor than before.  I just flip-flopped the numbers for aroma and flavor but overall this still gets a 4.2.
My favorite IPA! But there are many more to try!!

UPDATED: OCT 24, 2003 Rerate 10/21/03: After getting a sixer of Two Hearted this year, I have to bump the score up. This really is a top of the line IPA. 09/29/02 (3.8):There's hops it that there beer! This was a 'guest tap' at Barley's brewpub here in Columbus, and although I usually find it wrong to try beers outside of the brewpub where I am drinking, I'm glad I made an exception here. Cloudy orange color with a thin head. Strong hoppy, floral aroma. Hops dominate the flavor as well, bordering on the extreme. This beer will definitely keep your attention. Take a whiff of one of these during a boring meeting and you'll wake right up. You'll probably get fired but you'll be awake.

Hops, hops, hops.  Hops, hops, hops.  Hops, hops, hops.  Hops, hops, hops.  As you can tell by my little jingle, this beer is just packed with hops bite.  This is Bells to the extreme as far as hops are concerned.  The aroma was wonderful, sweet, and hoppy.  The flavor is of course hoppy too, rich and dark.  The appearance is your normal cloudy yellow/orange.  Now for the downside, the aftertaste is too hoppy.  I could stand it and enjoyed it with the flavor, but the aftertaste left something to be desired for me.  Im glad Bells makes this beer though.

Oh my, how I love this beer - and this isnt just a homer vote.  Its nothing but hops, hops and more hops - but in a good way.  A unique experience, a great buzz.  If youre drinking it for the first time, do it on a clean palette and drink nothing but 2 hearted all night long - trust me.
Got to love the hops in this one.  Nice flavors, but for the serious hop fan.  Not the first beer for someone coming off  Bud or Corona.

UPDATED: JAN 22, 2005 Early 2002 bottle (12 oz), sampled January 2005: nice release of CO<sub>2</sub>, with a column of foam growing right out of the bottle before I pour.  The first glass I poured without the yeast dregs: crystal clear gold with a generous off white foam that dies to the edge of the glass.  Thick caramel coated aged hop cones in a super-developed aroma.  Everyone in the bottle has been playing nicely: the hops have contributed their resin and hints of pine, and the malts have mustered up a great does of chewy caramel, peanut butter, and hints of raisins.  Though the aroma has developed extraordinarily, the palate is totally dead and the flavours are well on their way: thin and watery with a stale bitterness and no real hop presence (not unexpected, but a fun experiment).  My advice: stick with a fresh example (less than a year old), it is still one of my most favourite beers.

UPDATED: FEB 14, 2004 Light amber with frothy,soapy,lacey head.Favorite in the aroma department.Piney,bubblegum,citric hop aroma.Palate very full here also.Caramelly,bready,malty flavors are big. Hops are everywhere.Finish is citric,and leafy.Also,some Belgian malt flavors?Could be cause of the yeast I just added.Never loses thickness or flavor.Damn good!

This was very enjoyable.  Nice citrus in the nose.  Aroma reminded me more of an APA than what I think of in an IPA.  More mellow and malty in the body than an APA.  Nice bitterness.  Citrus again in the mouth, but also some doughy/bread flavor as well.  Very enjoyable.  Another fine product from Bells.

UPDATED: MAR 29, 2003 Pours cloudy copper color, citrus hoppy aroma, nice hop profile, crazy ass foamy clingy head. Juicy grapefruit-citrus flavors, medium bodied IPA with a nice rounded full mouthfeel, this may be the most drinkable IPA I have ever tasted, I just can"t stop at one.
Crazy bitter.  Not for me.  Looked good in the glass.  Cant figure out any of Bells labels.  My label had two ventricles, not two hearts.

Comments added 7/1/02: Not as big and bold as the Stone or Victory Hop Devil; actually somewhat mild for an IPA.  Lots of floral and citrus character in this one.  Original comments: First off: this is some niiiice stuff.  Mighty drinkable and pleasant.  Let it warm up a little from fridge temperature and you get the full ride.  Okay, for an IPA, its a bit unusual: fairly standard orange color, cloudy, good head, nice retention, hoppy aroma.  But get this one into your mouth and you get a sweet, smooth character to it that I didnt get with the Victory Hop Devil or Stones IPA.  Dont know what it is that gives it the sweetness and smoothness, but I quite like it.  Still plenty of hop bitterness to make this an IPA worth its style designation.  Well-balanced and yummy!

UPDATED: MAY 24, 2003 Even though the alcohol content is higher than I like, it takes awhile before it is evident. The citrus wasn't to overpowering and the drinkablity was good. Golden color and slightly cloudy.
a wonderfully hoppy IPA, citrus flavors, and a bitter aftertaste that is right up my alley. One of my favorite IPAs

Rerate: OK, now I get it. This is loaded with some other kinds of hops than those in West Coast IPAs, and also far more malty than most of those Ive tried. Its a big big beer, gentlemen. Still, lingering, there is a soft sweetness, not just citrus, but more flowery. And the trademark (IMO) biscuit, baked quality of the malts is truly evident. A great one. Rerate was 3.3 on 4/22/02: A year of lots of drinking and 6 months on ratebeer have finally matured my IPA sensibilities, and I can see this brew as the monster that is is. Pound all in: big hops, huge malt, thick and big. I see that now. Original: 12/01/01: My friends love this beer. It comes so highly recommended around here. I just dont enjoy it.
user_location: Łódż, Warsaw, Poland; Michigan, Ohio, USA

text: Best beer ever! Aggressively hopped in bitterness, flavor, and aroma. Balanced maltiness. Clean finish. Excellent.
Alright but honestly my least favorite bells.  Not really adventerous flavor but good for any nonadventerous beer drinkers.

UPDATED: OCT 9, 2003 Re-rate:  Nose of yeast, citrus, and hops.  Really biting, bitter hops with a slight mellowing sweetness developing in the middle and carrying through to the medium finish.  Overall dry finish.  Original: A beer with ultimate hops.  A very good, distinct beer.

UPDATED: OCT 19, 2003 Hazy apricot with a nice and frothy head. Wonderful bouquet of hops in the nose. Crisp, sharp and effervescent on the tongue. Excellent citrus flavors really came alive.
